On your next cook, after you've had a chance to live the high life with your fancy filet, feel free to drown it (and your vegetables while you're at it) in one of our sauces.

description.text:
Have you ever had a craving for a proper roasted turkey like halfway through summer, then felt down because the holiday season was months away? We know how it is. This recipe lets you live your dreams of a holiday feast at any time of year. Or you can save it for the actual season and just blow everyone's minds with the best turkey they've ever eaten.

If there's one fear every chef has in common around the holidays, it's serving up a dry bird. You can put that to rest, because MEATER will notify you when your turkey is ready, so you can sit back and relax without having to keep checking the oven. (Or you can keep pretending to check in case you need a break from your family.)

A classic holiday table includes a veritable buffet of hot side dishes, like roasted vegetables, potatoes, and gravy. You can stick to the classics or get creative with your own, as long as your guests leave with a full stomach and plenty of leftovers. If the food doesn't make you sleepy enough, just add a glass of white wine, or sparkling wine if you really feel like getting into the holiday spirit.

items.name: Whole Turkey
items.information:
10-12 lbs recommended

Should be thawed to room temperature before starting cook

meta.text: Pre-heat your oven to <temperature c="220" f="425" />. This can take up to 15m.

Just by virtue of their sheer heftiness, turkeys are likely to be close to the heat source in the oven, so it's best to start at a higher temperature and turn it down partway through the cook. You'll get your golden and crispy skin with the initial high temperature and with regular basting, but there's far less risk of serving up meat that makes your guests' mouths feel dry.
Remove the giblets from the cavity and defeather skin.

If you're someone who gets put off by the mere idea of a giblet, you're not alone. But we highly encourage you to steel yourself and set the giblets aside instead of throwing them away, because they can be used to make a spectacular homemade gravy or stock.

meta.pro_tip: Since you'll be manipulating the turkey skin to add the butter underneath, the skin needs to be soft and supple, so it shouldn't be dry brined. In cases where you won't be applying butter or seasonings under your poultry skin, you can crisp the skin by seasoning the bird 24h before cooking, then leaving it uncovered in the fridge.

meta.text: Pat your turkey dry with paper towels, inside and out.

You should always pat your meat dry so your butter and seasonings will stick better. If you bought your turkey pre-packaged at a grocery store, this also gets rid of any leftover liquid from the packaging.
Carefully run your fingers under the skin. Take your time to avoid tearing.

meta.pro_tip: If possible, getting some salt and pepper under the skin along with the butter can help to season the meat itself.

meta.text: Carefully rub your butter (Â¼ cup) under the skin.

If you're only applying butter on top of the skin, there's a chance that the flavor won't get deep into the meat while cooking. Putting butter directly on the meat will make your turkey more moist and give it a rich, buttery flavor. Fair warning, it's going to feel weird while you're doing it, but we promise it's worth it.
Massage butter (Â¼ cup) over the whole bird.

Oh, you thought we'd used enough butter already? There's no such thing! Covering the turkey with butter helps to crisp up the skin while roasting. You can use either salted or unsalted butter, though we recommend unsalted so that there's less risk of ending up with an overly briny bird.
Sprinkle salt and pepper all over and inside the cavity.
Adding salt and pepper in the cavity seasons the actual meat rather than just the skin.
Cut your lemon in half and toss it in the cavity.

Poultry and citrus always make an excellent combination. Lemon in particular makes the meat subtly tangy, and it tends to pair well with most herbs that are widely used for cooking poultry. Putting fresh lemon in the cavity of your turkey also adds moisture to the meat as it cooks.

meta.pro_tip: As an alternative, there's an extra bit of flesh on the sides of the cavity opening. You can cut a hole on each side, then cross the turkey legs and tuck them into the opposite end.

meta.text: Make a cut in the extra skin at the top of the cavity, and wrap it around the turkey legs.

The question of whether or not to truss has been a heated argument in recent years, with each side swearing that their method cooks the turkey more evenly. But do you want to know a secret? It doesn't actually make that much of a difference. As it turns out, tying the legs together is an aesthetic choice and is totally up to your preference. We like it because it's traditional, and it looks way more elegant than letting the turkey just stick its legs out however it feels in the moment. If you have kitchen twine handy, you can truss your turkey the old-fashioned way, but using the skin saves you a little bit of waste.
Set your MEATER charger close to the oven.

If you're using MEATER Plus or MEATER Block, the charging dock needs to stay as close to your cooker as possible so it can stay connected to the probe. From there, it'll boost the signal over Bluetooth or WiFi, depending on your model. If you're using the original MEATER, the charger won't have any repeater function, so you'll just want to keep your smart device close to the probe.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the breast.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the black ceramic handle, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Place the turkey on a rack over a tray.

Raised racks let heat flow all around the meat, which means better color and more even cooking. A foil-lined tray under the rack will seriously improve your life when it's time to clean up the kitchen. High five, past self.
Stick the turkey in the oven on the lowest rack.
You'll want to avoid having the turkey too close to the top. Like we mentioned earlier, it's already going to be close to the heat source, but it's best to give it as much room as you can.

meta.pro_tip: If you want a richer flavor, you can melt Â½ cup of duck or beef fat with your herb butter.

meta.text: Melt your remaining butter (Â½ cup) on medium low, and add herbs.

Rosemary is a popular herb for a classy and traditional roast turkey because it's aromatic without being overpowering. Sage, on the other hand, has a stronger and more peppery herbal flavor, but it goes well with holiday turkey. It also blends beautifully with both rosemary and lemon, which is why we liked it for this recipe.
Turn down your oven to <temperature c="180" f="350" />.
Brush the turkey with your herb butter every 20m.
Basting the turkey helps to keep it from drying out in the heat of the oven. Just be careful not to keep the oven open too long, because this can drag out the cook and counteract the basting.
Let your turkey rest on the rack.

Even though we'd normally tell you to rest meat on a room temperature surface, your turkey should stay on the rack in this case so that the juices can drip into the baking tray. These delicious drippings can also be used for gravy, but make sure to skim off the fat first.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Serve the turkey whole, and carve off sections as needed.

Everyone's got a favorite holiday side dish, so customize your plate with whatever makes you feel jolly. Hot buttered rolls? Excellent choice. Green bean casserole? Sure. Mashed potatoes and gravy? Yes please. Sweet potatoes? Only if they're loaded with brown sugar and marshmallows. Just make sure to wash it all down with a fancy flute full o' bubbly.

description.text:
There's nothing like a piping hot pile of pulled pork at a party, so it can be a struggle when it's too cold outside or when you live somewhere without access to a smoker. That's why we're here to heal your broken heart, and let you know that there's a way to make juicy, succulent pulled pork using your oven. It's a cinch to pull off, and it feeds a ton of people so you can be the most popular person at your next indoor luau.

Even though pulled pork is hard to mess up, it's still important to cook it properly so that the meat doesn't dry out. Not only will MEATER let you know when your pork is at its juiciest and most shreddable, but you can also set custom alerts to remind you to wrap it, which means you can focus all of your attention on party prep.

Pulled pork can be served with any of your favorite barbecue sides, so have fun creating your own personalized barbecue platter. Personally, we like fresh coleslaw to offset the heaviness of the pork. When it comes to drinks, there's nothing like cracking open a cold beer at a barbecue.

items.name: Pork Butt
items.information:
10-11 lbs recommended

Bone in recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: Baking Tray
items.information: Deep enough to hold 1-2 L of water

meta.text: Combine your dry ingredients.

Because we're using an oven instead of a smoker, we wanted a blend of spices that would give the pork a rich flavor. The cayenne pepper gives it a mild kick, and the cumin adds both bitterness and sweetness to make your pulled pork stand out. And even though this might be cheating, we opted for smoked paprika to add some smoky flavor. While you're cooking, the dry rub will caramelize and create a crust, which means you'll have more taste and more color.
Pat your entire pork butt dry with paper towels.

You should always pat your meat dry so your mustard and seasonings will stick better. If you bought your pork butt pre-packaged at a grocery store, this also gets rid of any leftover liquid from the packaging.
Coat the pork butt with your mustard (4 tbsp).

We can almost see you raising your eyebrow from here, but just hear us out. Spreading yellow mustard on a pork butt is actually a pretty common practice among seasoned pitmasters because it's less expensive than oil, and it creates a really nice, thick bark on the surface. Don't worry about changing the taste of the meat, because the mustard loses flavor while it sits in the oven. Just make sure you're using classic yellow mustard, because spicy, creamy, or ground varieties can easily mess with the taste and texture of your pork.

meta.pro_tip: If you'd like your crust even crispier on your next cook, you can season the pork butt 24h before cooking, then leave it uncovered in the fridge to dry brine.

meta.text: Sprinkle your rub all over and pat it in.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the pork butt.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the black ceramic handle, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.

steps.title: Put Pork in Oven and Add Water

meta.pro_tip: For easier cleanup, line the tray with aluminum foil. After cooking, you can also save the water with the pork drippings to moisturize the meat if you need to reheat it.

meta.text: Place the pork butt fat side up on a rack over a tray, pop it in the oven, then pour 1-2 L of cold water in the tray.

Raised racks let heat flow all around the meat, which means better color and more even cooking. There are benefits to cooking both top side up and bottom side up, but we like to keep the fatty side of the pork butt at the top while cooking so that the fat can soak into the meat and not just drip off. As the oven heats up, the water in the baking tray will create a nice little sauna to make the pork more moist and tender.
Set your oven to <temperature c="120" f="250" />.

For this recipe, it's better to set the oven right when you're adding the meat instead of letting it pre-heat beforehand. This is mostly because you don't want to add the water when the oven is already hot, but the gradual rise in temperature also helps with the low and slow cooking process.
Loosely wrap the pork in foil with the probe poking out, and let it rest covered for 2-4h.

The longer you give your pork butt to rest, the more time the juices will have to redistribute throughout the meat. Because bigger cuts need a longer resting time, wrapping your pork in foil and covering it with a towel helps to retain heat.
Cover the wrapped pork butt with a kitchen towel. Leave it to rest at room temperature for a minimum of 30m, or ideally 2-4h.
The longer you give your pork butt to rest, the more time the juices will have to redistribute throughout the meat, and the more juicy and tender your end result will be.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Unwrap your pork butt, and throw away the bone and cartilage.
Okay, we know we literally just said to throw away any cartilage you find, but we also won't judge you if you want to eat it.

meta.pro_tip: If you choose to use finishing salt and pepper, salt flakes and freshly ground peppercorns will give you more flavor and add a little extra crunch to your pulled pork.

meta.text: Shred the pork into thin strands with shredding claws or two large forks.

description.text: You can't have a proper barbecue without a flavorful barbecue sauce. While there is a wide variety of styles readily available at the grocery store, making your own barbecue sauce at home is so quick and easy, and you'll have complete control over the ingredients and the flavor. With so many options available, we wanted to bring a unique sauce to the table, so we created this recipe to pair with your favorite MEATER barbecue creations. You can follow our recipe, or you can use it as a base and add more of your favorite ingredients to create something truly special. Either way, this sauce will take your parties to the next level!

meta.text: Squeeze 1 lemon (between 3 and 5 tbsp, depending on the size of the lemon) into a saucepan.
Since this recipe uses apple cider vinegar which has a lighter flavor, we chose to add lemon juice to give our sauce the distinctively tangy taste we were aiming for.
Pour your ketchup (1Â¼ cup), sugar (Â½ cup), Worcestershire sauce (Â½ cup), and vinegar (â…“ cup) into the pan with the lemon juice.

All of these ingredients are commonly used in barbecue sauce recipes in order to hit the sweet, smoky, and tangy flavor profiles all at once. For our sauce, we used raw cane sugar and apple cider vinegar specifically to achieve a beautiful deep red color. The golden cane sugar also has a thicker, more syrupy texture as it melts, and it brings a slight caramel taste to your sauce. Additionally, since most of the ingredients have an incredibly long shelf life, the sauce will keep for several weeks in the refrigerator.

Simmer your sauce for at least 20m, stirring occasionally, until the ingredients are fully blended and the sauce thickens to your desired consistency. Take care while stirring, as the sauce will get extremely hot and can bubble quite a bit due to the sugar content.

It's important to keep the temperature as low as you can to avoid burning the sauce, and to pay special attention to the sides of the pan while stirring. We recommend simmering for 20m, but you can leave it on slightly longer if you want your sauce to reduce and thicken further. This will also make the sauce sweeter as the sugar cooks.
Remove your pan from the heat and allow it to cool for just a few minutes.
Gently mix in your maple syrup (2 tbsp), cayenne pepper (1 tsp), and paprika (1 tsp) into the pan, then stir your sauce continuously for 2m until the remaining ingredients are completely combined.

Since syrup has already been cooked, it doesn't need to be boiled along with the rest of the ingredients, as this can change the consistency and make your sauce too thick. The spices will release more flavor when cooked, so it's best to add them after the pan has been removed from the heat to avoid the spicy and smoky flavors being too overpowering.
Pour your sauce into a room temperature dish and allow it to cool for 10m.
The melted sugar in the sauce makes it extremely hot right after cooking, so it must be left to cool in order to prevent burns.

Serve your sauce on top of your favorite protein, either in a sandwich or just a la carte. You can also cook with the sauce by brushing it onto your meat, or even using it on pizza in place of red sauce.

description.text: Argentinian Chimichurri is an incredibly versatile sauce. It can be used in cooking as a marinade, or just served on the side as a condiment. The ingredient measurements are not an exact science, so it's a highly customizable sauce. You can use more or less of any ingredient to suit your preference, or you can follow our recommendations to taste how we like it. To give you more control over your flavor, we chose not to specify what kind of red chili pepper to use, so you can choose any kind you like!

items.name: 3 Red Chilies
items.information: Choose your favorite type to customize sauce to your taste

items.name: 1 Tbsp Dried Oregano
items.information: Can be dried from fresh in an oven or a dehydrator, or hung in the sun

items.name: Salt to Taste
items.information:
Himalayan or Maldon salt flakes recommended

Table salt can be used (no more than 1/2 Tsp)

meta.text: Wash your parsley (1 bunch) with cold water and dry it with a paper towel. Cut off the lower, more fibrous parts of the stems, then finely chop the leaves.

Parsley is one of the most versatile herbs available, and can be used in a large variety of dishes. We recommend using Italian flat leaf parsley over curly parsley because it has a much more bold and intense flavor. When selecting parsley, you can rub a little bit in your hands, then smell your hands to make sure it has a strong aroma.
Peel and mince your garlic (4 cloves).
Remove the stems and seeds from your chili peppers (3), then finely chop them. Be sure to wash your hands thoroughly after this step.

While you can use a food processor in a pinch, you'll get the best results from chopping your ingredients by hand. This gives you more control over the texture of the sauce, and all of the different colors will be more noticeable, especially the pops of red from the peppers.
Squeeze half of a lemon (about 1 to 2 tbsp) into the bowl.
Lemon juice adds acidity and tanginess to balance out the powerful earthy flavors of the parsley and oregano.

meta.pro_tip: Fresh oregano is harder to find, but if you can get your hands on it, we suggest drying it yourself at home to add even more flavor. The best way to dry oregano is in a dehydrator on its lowest setting. If you don't have access to one, you can also use your oven, or put the fresh oregano in a perforated paper bag and hang it in the sun.

meta.text: Add your oregano (1 tbsp).

Oregano is one of the most powerful herbs, and is rare in that it retains most of the same flavor when dried, unlike most herbs which will change slightly in flavor. Using it dried instead of fresh will add more layers of texture and color to your sauce.
Add your red wine vinegar (1 tbsp).

Whenever possible, it's best to use high-quality, well aged red wine vinegar. Cheaper vinegars that are produced quickly have a much more harsh and sour taste. As the vinegar is allowed to age, the flavor becomes much more mellow and complex. Some vinegars are also aged in toasted oak barrels which adds a slight smoky taste.
Add your olive oil (200 mL).
Though we caution against using extra virgin olive oil over heat due to its low smoke point, it's ideal for cold sauces like this one because of its more pungent flavor.
Season your sauce with salt and pepper to taste.

Using salt flakes and freshly ground peppercorns will make the flavor stand out, as well as give you some added crunch. Salt flakes also give you more control over how much you're putting in so you don't overdo it. While you can use black pepper for this recipe, freshly ground rainbow peppercorns bring an aromatic blend of flavors to make your sauce a bit more unique.

Mix the ingredients together. Your sauce can be served right away, though we recommend covering it with plastic cling wrap and refrigerating it for at least an hour. This allows the flavors to fully combine for a more flavorful sauce, and laying plastic cling wrap right on top of the sauce also helps to prevent oxidation and preserve the color.

meta.pro_tip: If possible, we suggest using all of the sauce within 24h. Beyond that, it may start to lose its vivid green color due to the acidity of the lemon and vinegar.

meta.text: Serve the sauce with your favorite protein.

description.text:
You can (and should) put this stuff on practically anything. It's insanely simple to whip up a nice garlic butter at home, and it's easy to tweak to your preference if you want to use different herbs or flavorings. Personally, we like fresh parsley and chives for color and flavor, and just a touch of lemon juice to add a little something extra.

This butter makes a decadent, flavorful topper for just about any cut of steak, and we've added a few combined recipes in our recipe menu if you want to cook your favorite cut of steak and your garlic butter at the same time. You'll also get a ton of servings with this recipe, so if you run out of steak, go ahead and throw a healthy dollop on your seafood or vegetables. Or just buy more steak.

meta.pro_tip: If you have the time, we recommend leaving your butter out for 2 hours to soften before mixing in the other ingredients. You can microwave it in a pinch, but be careful not to completely melt it.

meta.text: Dice your butter (1 cup) into 1" squares.
If you've only got salted butter in your fridge, don't worry, we won't tattle on you. We only recommend unsalted butter so that there's less risk of going overboard when you add salt later.
Cut off the stems and finely chop the leaves (1 tbsp).

Parsley is one of the strongest herbs, so we chose it to add a powerful peppery flavor to our butter. While you can experiment with using different herbs to your taste, we recommend parsley because its leafy texture won't disturb the smoothness of your butter like some more needly herbs. Parsley also adds a pop of bright color, and it makes your butter healthier. That's what we tell ourselves, anyway.
Thinly slice your chives until you have 2 tsp.

Chives give your butter a nice onion taste without overpowering the other flavors, and they work well with the parsley to make your butter more colorful. We also recommend chives over other onion varieties because they won't make the butter quite as chunky.
Peel and mince your garlic (4 cloves).

Ah, garlic. An ingredient so delicious and versatile that it has its own butter. We wanted this recipe to be customizable, so if you're like us and are never satisfied with the suggested garlic amount in recipes, you can feel free to go nuts.
Squeeze your lemon juice (2 tbsp, or about Â½ of a medium-sized lemon).

Other garlic butters may include herbs and onions like ours, but lemon juice is our own special twist on the recipe (please pardon the pun). The acidity adds a contrast to the other flavors to give the butter more complexity, and the liquid element makes it easier to mix the ingredients together.
Sprinkle your white pepper (2 tsp) and salt to taste into the butter.

We chose white pepper both because the earthy flavor complements the herbs in the butter, and because it just looks less speckly in lighter sauces. With the salt, we recommend using flakes for better flavor, for a nice little crunch, and because it's easier to control the amount so you don't overdo it.
Stir the butter well. Taste it and add seasoning as needed.
Roll your butter into a sheet of parchment paper and twist it closed.

meta.pro_tip: If you have any butter left over, you can keep it wrapped and leave it in the freezer, and it will keep for a long time. Just make sure to move it to the fridge a little bit before serving, or it'll be really difficult to cut through.

meta.text: Place your butter roll in the fridge for 20-30m to set.

Rolling and chilling your butter helps you cut clean, circular pats to give your food a more professional presentation. If you're too anxious to taste that garlicky goodness and don't want to wait, you can use a melon baller to scoop out cute lil' butter balls.
Serve the butter on your favorite protein, on vegetables, or on toast.

description.text:
Who says you have to drop a fortune to eat well? Even inexpensive cuts like this one can be beautifully tender and flavorful when they're done right. Sirloin has a characteristic fat layer along one side, and when you do a slow cook followed by a quick reverse sear with the fat side first, that layer keeps the steak juicy and creates a veritable flavor explosion in the meat while it cooks. Plus, more affordable steaks like this one are pretty easy to find in most grocery stores, so you won't be going on a whole expedition just to find something to cook for dinner.

The trick to a gourmet sirloin is taking your time. Since it doesn't have as much marbling as rib-eye, it can dry out if it's overcooked. Low and slow cooking is the best way to avoid this, along with using MEATER to make sure you're hitting the perfect internal temperature.

When it comes to side dishes for sirloin, we like to keep it simple with roasted vegetables or a good ol' beef and potatoes meal. You can also find a variety of mouth-watering sauces in our recipe menu if you want to add some flair to your sirloin. If you're looking for a perfect beverage pairing, you'll find the best balance with something acidic, like a fruity and full-bodied red wine like cabernet sauvignon, or a citrusy IPA.

items.name: Sirloin Steak
items.information:
About 1Â½" thick recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: Oil
items.information:
Just enough to lightly coat the pan

Oils with higher smoke point recommended, like avocado or grapeseed oil

meta.text: Pre-heat your oven to <temperature c="120" f="250" />. This can take up to 15m.

You might be tempted to trim off the thick layer of fat on the side of your steak, but we urge you to back away from the knife. This isn't to say you can't trim the fat, but we recommend not doing this until you're ready to eat. Since sirloin is a leaner cut, it has a reputation for being tough and chewy, but leaving the fat on will impart a lot of flavor and tenderness into the meat during the cook.
Sprinkle salt and pepper all over, and pat it in.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the steak.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the black ceramic handle, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Set your MEATER charger close to the oven.

If you're using MEATER Plus or MEATER Block, the charging dock needs to stay as close to your cooker as possible so it can stay connected to the probe. From there, it'll boost the signal over Bluetooth or WiFi, depending on your model. If you're using the original MEATER, the charger won't have any repeater function, so you'll just want to keep your smart device close to the probe.
Place the steak on a rack and pop it in the oven.

Raised racks let heat flow all around the meat, which means better color and more even cooking. A foil-lined tray under the rack will seriously improve your life when it's time to clean up the kitchen. High five, past self.
Let your steak rest on a cutting board.

Carryover cooking lasts a lot longer on a hot surface, so smaller cuts like this one need to be moved to a room temperature surface after you take them off of heat. If not, your medium rare steak may be closer to medium, or your well done steak may be closer to shoe leather.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Pat your steak dry with paper towels.
Leftover moisture on your steak will make it steam instead of sear. This is great for a spa day, but not so much for getting a beautiful crust.
Oil your pan, and pre-heat it on high for 1m.
Sear the fat edge until a golden crust forms.

Remember when we talked about leaving the fat on the steak while you're cooking? You're about to find out why! If you sear the fat edge before the rest of the steak, it renders into the pan to keep your steak juicy. If you do want to eat it with the fat on, directly searing that edge will make it an extra crispy treat.
Sear the rest of the steak just until it's golden brown.

The point of this step is just to create a crust right on the surface of the steak, not to cook the steak more. Make sure not to leave it in the pan any longer than it takes to get the right texture, or the meat might overcook.

meta.pro_tip: If you choose to use finishing salt and pepper, salt flakes and freshly ground peppercorns will give you more flavor and add a little extra crunch to your steak.

meta.text: Serve your sirloin whole or sliced.

If you want some extra points for presentation, we recommend slicing the steak into Â½" pieces and arranging them nicely on a plate. As an alternative, if you're making the steak for someone else, you can serve it whole and let that person cut through the crispy seared outside. Either way, we suggest giving it a mild sprinkling of finishing salt and pepper, then serving it up with potatoes and red wine.

description.text: When you're looking to give your guests a break from the mundane, our green peppercorn sauce brings the classic elements of fine French cuisine right to your table. This creamy and decadent sauce will bring a bold, peppery flavor to your meal without taking it over. It pairs best with your favorite cut of beef, but you can drizzle it on any of your MEATER proteins!

items.name: â…” Cup Beef Stock
items.information:
Low-sodium or no-salt stock recommended

Low-sodium vegetable stock can be substituted

meta.text: Mince your Â½ shallot.
Shallots are commonly used in sauces because their flavor is milder and more refined than other onion types. As they cook, they also release a subtle sweetness.
Wash your parsley with cold water and dry it with a paper towel. Cut off the lower, more fibrous parts of the stems, then finely chop the leaves until you have 1 tbsp.
Parsley is a strong herb with a bit of a peppery flavor, so it works well with this pepper-based sauce. It also adds a nice bit of color to the final product.

meta.pro_tip: We recommend using a stainless steel pan or a cast iron skillet because they'll help your ingredients to brown more easily, and you'll get a lot of nice caramelization in your sauce.

meta.text: If you're using brined peppercorns, they should be rinsed before cooking, but make sure not to crush them. If you're using dry peppercorns, they should be ground, but don't make them too fine. Once the peppercorns are prepared, place your pan on the stove on high heat, then add olive oil (1 tbsp). SautÃ© the shallots and peppercorns for 2-3m until the shallots are golden brown and the peppercorns release a fresh, peppery aroma.

Green peppercorns are the same species as black peppercorns, and the difference is simply that the green peppercorns are harvested before they're fully ripe. When they're picked earlier, the peppercorns have a less pungent and more aromatic flavor. This is ideal for sauces, since the taste of the green peppercorns is less likely to overpower whatever you're pairing with the sauce.

Deglaze the pan with your brandy (â…“ cup). If you're using a gas stove with open flame, remove the pan from the burner while adding alcohol. Scrape any caramelized bits from the sides of the pan and stir them in.

In French cuisine, it's common to find brandy, shallots, mustard, and pepper in recipes together. Deglazing your pan with brandy helps to caramelize your ingredients and add a nice flavor to your sauce, and even though it's strong on its own, it will evaporate during reduction and allow the tastes of the other ingredients to concentrate.

meta.pro_tip: For the best tasting sauce, we recommend making your own no-salt beef stock at home.

meta.text: Pour your beef stock (â…” cup) into the pan.

Liquid is needed when you're reducing a sauce, and beef stock has the added benefit of providing flavor and color. It's also a perfect choice since this sauce goes best with a high-quality steak. Your sauce will become saltier as it reduces, so it's best to use a low-sodium or no-salt stock.
Reduce the heat, then pour your heavy cream (â…” cup) into the pan. Continue stirring the sauce gently for 1m.

Heavy cream will make your sauce creamy without altering the flavor the way that a roux made from flour and butter would. If heavy cream is cooked at a high temperature, it can separate and alter the texture of your sauce, so it's important to turn down the heat before adding the cream.
Stir your mustard (1 tsp) into the sauce.
Dijon mustard will add to the pleasant creamy color of this sauce, and it brings just a hint of pungent spiciness.
Simmer and reduce the sauce just until it's thick enough to coat your spoon or spatula. Keep stirring occasionally to avoid any sauce burning on the edges of the pan.
Remove your pan from the heat, then stir in your chopped parsley.
Taste your sauce, and add as much salt as you'd like to adjust the recipe to your preference.
Serve the sauce with your favorite cut of beef or the protein of your choice.

description.text:
Brace yourselves, it's about to get hot in here. This is a traditional Portuguese recipe with an exotic blend of flavors that hit nearly every flavor palate. It's usually made with peri peri peppers (or African bird's eye chilis), but we swapped them out for habanero peppers since they've got more heat with a little sweet. Fair warning, though: Habanero peppers fall between 100,000 and 350,000 on the Scoville scale, which is basically a fancy way of saying that you should maybe have some milk nearby to stop the burning.

This sauce is perfect for dipping, so serve it up with chicken wings or snacky vegetables the next time you have people over. It also makes an amazing marinade for chicken or fish if you're looking to spice up your dinnertime.

items.name: 2 Habanero Peppers
items.information:
If unavailable, substitute serrano or jalapeÃ±o peppers

Habanada peppers can be used for less heat

items.name: 1 Tablespoon Molasses
items.information:
Pure sugar cane molasses recommended

If unavailable, substitute pomegranate molasses

items.name: â…“ Cup Olive Oil
items.information: Pure (not virgin or extra virgin) olive oil recommended due to higher smoke point

meta.text: Cut off the lower parts of your cilantro stems.

Cilantro is a great complement to poultry dishes because it has a bit of a citrus flavor. It also has a strong herby flavor, so it's a perfect addition to a bold sauce like peri peri. Unless, of course, you have that weird olfactory gene variation that makes cilantro taste like soap.

meta.pro_tip: If you're curious about the habanero flavor but can't take the heat, there is a miracle of science called a habanada pepper, though this might be tricky to find in the wild.

meta.text: Cut the stems from your habanero peppers (2), then wash your hands.

We wanted this recipe to have a lot of heat while still maintaining flavor, so we chose habanero peppers for their unique sweet and spicy taste. After cooking, the chicken itself might be mild enough that it can be enjoyed by even the wimpiest of spice wimps, but our recipe calls for some uncooked sauce to be set aside (spoiler alert) for those who like to live dangerously. If you want your sauce to be less spicy, you can use fewer peppers, as well as remove the seeds and pith.
Pick off the stems from your basil leaves (15).

Basil is an aromatic herb with a touch of sweetness, so it helps to balance out the spiciness of the peppers and the acidity of the lemon juice. It's important to remove the stems, because no one likes a chewy sauce.
Peel your garlic (4 cloves).

Garlic is almost as much of a staple in savory dishes as salt and pepper. It's a powerhouse of flavor that pairs with and enhances foods of every flavor profile. Do you really need to add garlic to all of your recipes? That's like asking if you really need oxygen.

meta.pro_tip: If you can only find fresh bell peppers, roast them for 25m at <temperature c="200" f="400" />, then remove the stems, skin, and seeds.

meta.text: Pat your peppers dry with paper towels.

Bell peppers are a big source of freshness and color in this sauce, but since raw bell peppers have a high water content, they have to be roasted. If the sauce is blended with fresh bell pepper, it will be way too watery, and you'll just end up marinating the baking tray instead of the chicken.

Put the following ingredients in the blender:
  • Habanero peppers
  • Cilantro
  • Basil
  • Garlic
  • Roasted red peppers
It's always best to put solid ingredients in the blender first, especially leafy ones. Otherwise, it's easier for chunky bits to get stuck at the top of the blender where they won't mix in properly.
Add in the rest of the sauce ingredients.
This combination of ingredients makes a beautifully thick and colorful sauce, and gives it a lot of complexity in its flavor. Your chicken will be spicy, smoky, tangy, and just a little bit sweet.
Blend the ingredients on high speed until your sauce reaches a thick consistency.
Serve the sauce as a dip for chicken wings and vegetables, or use it as a marinade for your favorite protein.

description.text:
We're almost afraid to share this with you, because there's a risk it might ruin food for you forever. This recipe has everything: high-end beef, garlic, butter, a smidgen of fresh produce in there for good measure...and that's pretty much all of your food groups. And we haven't even gotten to the flavor yet. Filet mignon cooked low and slow with MEATER and reverse seared is already a tasty treat, but slapping on some of our garlic butter makes for one of the most decadent, melt-in-your-mouth indulgences you'll ever have.

A classy cut of beef like this one deserves side dishes that are just as sophisticated. SautÃ©ed vegetables will add color to your plate, and you can do your own elevated take on beef and potatoes with some cheesy scalloped potatoes. You won't want a wine that might overpower the more subtle flavor of the beef, so milder reds like pinot noir are a good idea.

items.name: Filet Mignon
items.information:
About 2" thick recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: Oil
items.information:
Just enough to lightly coat the pan

Oils with higher smoke point recommended, like avocado or grapeseed oil

meta.pro_tip: If you have the time, we recommend leaving your butter out for 2 hours to soften before mixing in the other ingredients. You can microwave it in a pinch, but be careful not to completely melt it.

meta.text: Dice your butter (1 cup) into small squares.
If you've only got salted butter in your fridge, don't worry, we won't tell on you. We only recommend unsalted butter so that there's less risk of going overboard when you add salt later.
Cut off your parsley stems and finely chop the leaves (1 tbsp).

Parsley is one of the strongest herbs, so we chose it to add a powerful peppery flavor to our butter. While you can experiment with using different herbs to your taste, we recommend parsley because its leafy texture won't disturb the smoothness of your butter like some more needly herbs. Parsley also adds a pop of bright color, and it makes your butter healthier. That's what we tell ourselves, anyway.
Thinly slice your chives until you have 2 tsp.

Chives give your butter a nice onion taste without overpowering the other flavors, and they work well with the parsley to make your butter more colorful. We also recommend chives over other onion varieties because they won't make the butter quite as chunky.
Peel and mince your garlic (4 cloves).

Ah, garlic. An ingredient so delicious and versatile that it has its own butter. We wanted this recipe to be customizable, so if you're like us and are never satisfied with the suggested garlic amount in recipes, you can feel free to go nuts.
Squeeze your lemon juice (2 tbsp, or about Â½ of a medium-sized lemon).

Other garlic butters may include herbs and onions like ours, but lemon juice is our own special twist on the recipe (please pardon the pun). The acidity adds a contrast to the other flavors to give the butter more complexity, and the liquid element makes it easier to mix the ingredients together.
Sprinkle your white pepper (2 tsp) and a pinch of salt into the butter.

We chose white pepper both because the earthy flavor complements the herbs in the butter, and because it just looks less speckly in lighter sauces. With the salt, we recommend using flakes for better flavor, for a nice little crunch, and because it's easier to control the amount so you don't overdo it.
Stir the butter well. Taste it and add seasoning as needed.
Roll your butter into a sheet of parchment paper and twist it closed.

meta.pro_tip: If you have any butter left over, you can keep it wrapped and leave it in the freezer, and it will keep for a long time. Just make sure to move it to the fridge a little bit before serving, or it'll be really difficult to cut through.

meta.text: Put your butter roll in the fridge for 20-30m to set.

Rolling and chilling your butter helps you cut clean, circular pats to give your food a more professional presentation. If you're too anxious to taste that garlicky goodness and don't want to wait, you can use a melon baller to scoop out cute lil' butter balls.
Pre-heat your oven to <temperature c="120" f="250" />. This can take up to 15m.

We know, waiting for your food to cook isn't always fun. But as much as you may want to just throw your filet in a blacksmithing forge so it can be done in like 30s, the best way to bring out this cut's characteristic tenderness is by cooking low and slow.

meta.pro_tip: For a more professional presentation, you can wrap kitchen twine around your filet to give it a cylindrical shape.

meta.text: Sprinkle salt and pepper all over and pat it in.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the filet.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the ambient sensor joint, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Place the filet on a rack and pop it in the oven.

Set your MEATER charger close to the oven.

title: Reverse Seared Filet Mignon
short_title: Filet Mignon with Porcini Mushroom Sauce
subtitle: Served with Porcini Mushroom Sauce

description.text:
This is the perfect recipe for those times when you feel like a classic salt-and-pepper filet mignon just isn't fancy enough. Just kidding, no one has ever thought that. But still, if you're feeling ambitious on a special occasion and really want to knock your filet mignon into the statosphere, you need a sauce that's worthy of such a high-end cut of beef. Porcini mushrooms are considered a luxury ingredient, not just because they're tricky to find and cultivate, but also because of their deep and autumnal flavor that makes them so unique. Cooking them up in this creamy blend will give you a truly magical mushroom sauce to elevate your filet mignon. No, not that kind of magic mushroom sauce. It just tastes crazy good.

A classy cut of beef like this one deserves side dishes that are just as sophisticated. SautÃ©ed vegetables will add color to your plate, and you can do your own elevated take on beef and potatoes with a garlic and herb mash or some cheesy scalloped potatoes. You won't want a wine that might overpower the more subtle flavor of the beef, so milder reds like pinot noir are a good idea.

items.name: Filet Mignon
items.information:
About 2" thick recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: Oil
items.information:
Just enough to lightly coat the pan

Oils with higher smoke point recommended, like avocado or grapeseed oil

items.name: 1 Cup Beef Stock
items.information:
Low-sodium or no-salt stock recommended

Low-sodium vegetable stock can be substituted

items.name: 2 Tablespoons Olive Oil
items.information: Pure (not virgin or extra virgin) olive oil recommended due to higher smoke point

meta.text: Soak your mushrooms (Â½ cup) in your wine (Â½ cup) for 10m.

Fresh porcini mushrooms can be hard to hunt down, need really specific growing conditions, and have to be carefully cultivated. As you can imagine, all of this adds up to a hefty price tag. To save our wallets some pain, we chose to use dried mushrooms for this recipe. Soaking them in wine gives them some extra flavor, and it also adds moisture to the mushrooms to revive them and make them easier to chop.
Finely chop your Â½ shallot.
Shallots are popular in sauces because their flavor is milder and more refined than some other onions. While they're cooking, they also release a subtle sweetness.
Squeeze the extra wine from your mushrooms, then roughly chop them up. Set the wine aside.
Pre-heat your oven to <temperature c="120" f="250" />. This can take up to 15m.

We know, waiting for your food to cook isn't always fun. But as much as you may want to just throw your filet in a blacksmithing forge so it can be done in like 30s, the best way to bring out this cut's characteristic tenderness is by cooking low and slow.

meta.pro_tip: For a more professional presentation, you can wrap kitchen twine around your filet to give it a cylindrical shape.

meta.text: Sprinkle salt and pepper all over and pat it in.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the filet.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the ambient sensor joint, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Place the filet on a rack and pop it in the oven.

Raised racks let heat flow all around the meat, which means better color and more even cooking. A foil-lined tray under the rack will seriously improve your life when it's time to clean up the kitchen. High five, past self.
Set your MEATER charger close to the oven.

From there, it'll boost the signal over Bluetooth or WiFi, depending on your model. If you're using the original MEATER, the charger won't have any repeater function, so you'll just want to keep your smart device close to the probe.
Let your filet rest on a cutting board.

Carryover cooking lasts a lot longer on a hot surface, so smaller cuts like this one need to be moved to a room temperature surface after you take them off of heat. If not, your medium rare filet may be closer to medium, or your well done filet may be closer to a hockey puck.
Add your oil (1 tbsp) to your pan. SautÃ© the shallots on high heat until they're translucent, stirring frequently.

As a general rule, when sautÃ©ing multiple ingredients, allium vegetables (look at us with the scientific terms!) like onions and garlic should always be added before anything else. This releases the flavor into the cooking oil, and it can be absorbed more easily by the other ingredients.
Add the mushrooms to the pan, and keep stirring until the shallots turn lightly brown.

After you've sautÃ©ed your shallots, the mushrooms should be added to the pan before any liquid so that they can be exposed to the direct heat and release their flavor. The same goes for any recipe that calls for sautÃ©ing vegetables.
Take the pan off of heat if you're cooking on open flame. Deglaze the pan with 2-3 tbsp of your wine, then put it back on the burner and let it evaporate for 2m.
Since most of the flavors in this sauce are deep and earthy, we suggest sticking with a dry wine like cabernet sauvignon or pinot noir so that the sauce won't get too sweet.
Drop the heat to medium low, and pour in your heavy cream (1 cup).

For sauces like this one that need to be boiled and reduced, there has to be a thick liquid element. Heavy cream will make your sauce--well, creamy, but it won't alter the flavor like a roux made from flour and butter.

meta.pro_tip: On your next cook, you can try making your own beef stock to really customize your flavor. Just make sure to leave out the salt, because this will give you better control over the amount of salt in the mushroom sauce when it's time for seasoning.

meta.text: Pour in your beef stock (1 cup).

Liquid is a necessity when you're reducing a sauce, and beef stock has the added benefit of providing flavor and color. It's also a perfect choice since this sauce goes best with a high-quality steak. Your sauce will get saltier as it reduces, so it's best to use a low-sodium or no-salt stock.

meta.pro_tip: If you have any stock left over, you can save it for when you need to reheat the sauce. This will help to keep the sauce from reducing too much or solidifying during reheating.

meta.text: Simmer and reduce the sauce just until it coats your spoon. Keep stirring occasionally to avoid burnt sauce on the edges of the pan.

Watch that you don't reduce the sauce too much, or the cream might burn or separate. If the sauce is too thick, you won't be able to get any of it through the sieve, but you can add in a little extra beef stock to thin it out if this happens.
Taste your sauce and add seasoning as needed.
Strain the sauce through your sieve.

Even though our recipe says to strain out the mushrooms and shallots so that you'll have a smooth and creamy sauce, it's really a matter of preference. If you want to enjoy a chunky mushroom sauce, or if you aren't a fan of food waste, feel free to skip this step. Or alternatively, strain the sauce but use the extra bits as a topper. We just want you to be happy and live your best life.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Pat your filet dry with paper towels.
Leftover moisture on your filet will make it steam instead of sear. This is great for a spa day, but not so much for getting a beautiful crust.
Oil your pan, and pre-heat it on high for 1m.
Sear your filet all over, just until it's golden brown.

The point of this step is just to create a crust right on the surface of the filet, not to cook the filet more. Make sure not to leave it in the pan any longer than it takes to get the right texture, or the meat might overcook.
Serve your filet mignon whole or thinly sliced, and drizzle your mushroom sauce on top.
If you want some extra points for presentation, we recommend slicing the filet into thin pieces and arranging them nicely on a plate before letting the mushroom sauce flow.

description.text:
From homey burger joints to high-end steakhouses, you'll find beef and blue cheese combos all over the place. The sharpness and texture of the cheese provide a beautiful contrast to the deep beefy flavor without detracting from the meat, so it's pretty easy to suss out why the two are such an inseparable pair. The only downside (and we mean the ONLY downside) is that a quality steak topped with blue cheese doesn't usually come cheap, so we did the only reasonable thing, which was to come up with a recipe to make it at home. We picked gorgonzola for this recipe both for its unique creaminess, and because it's among the mildest of the blue cheeses. A juicy filet mignon cooked to perfection with MEATER and topped with our gorgonzola sauce is so decadent, you might just have to start wearing a top hat and monocle everywhere you go.

A classy cut of beef like this one deserves side dishes that are just as sophisticated. SautÃ©ed vegetables will add color to your plate, and you can do your own elevated take on beef and potatoes with a garlic and herb mash. You won't want a wine that might overpower the more subtle flavor of the beef, so milder reds like pinot noir are a good idea.

meta.pro_tip: Heating up your knife by dipping it in hot water will make it easier to dice your cheese. It also helps for the cheese to be completely cold so it won't stick to your knife.

meta.text: Roughly dice your cheese (Â½ cup).

Contrary to popular belief, your cheese doesn't have to be rank to be fancy. Gorgonzola has a strong enough flavor to hold its own with your steak, but it's one of the milder and less aggressive blue cheeses, so we chose it for the sake of anyone whose nose is running for cover at the mere thought of a more pungent variety.

If you're using the original MEATER, the charger won't have any repeater function, so you'll just want to keep your smart device close to the probe.

Put your cheese and heavy cream (Â½ cup) in a pan on medium low, and whisk every 1-2m, just until the cheese melts.

Heavy cream will make your sauce nice and thick without altering the flavor as much as a roux. If heavy cream is cooked at too high a temperature, it can separate and mess with the texture of your sauce, so keep the heat down as much as possible.

meta.pro_tip: On your next cook, you can try making your own beef stock to really customize your flavor. Just make sure to leave out the salt, because this will give you better control over the amount of salt in the gorgonzola sauce when it's time for seasoning.

meta.text: Pour in your beef stock (Â½ cup).

You need liquid when you're reducing a sauce, and beef stock has the extra benefit of adding color. Plus, it's a perfect flavor choice since this sauce goes best with a top-drawer steak. Your sauce will get saltier as it reduces, so it's better to use a low-sodium or no-salt stock.
Drop your sage (3 leaves) into the sauce.

Sage has its own strong and deeply herbal flavor, and it's great for bringing out the tastes of lots of different cheeses. The sage leaves should be strained out before serving so that the flavor doesn't permeate the whole sauce over time (and also because you probably don't want to bite into a surprise leaf in the middle of a classy meal), but when they're just left in for cooking, they give a pleasant peppery taste to the creamy gorgonzola.

meta.pro_tip: If you have any stock left over, you can save it for when you need to reheat the sauce. This will help to keep the sauce from reducing too much or solidifying during reheating.

meta.text: Simmer and reduce the sauce just until it coats your spoon. Keep whisking occasionally to avoid burnt sauce on the edges of the pan.
If the sauce reduces and thickens too much, you won't be able to get any of it through the sieve, but you can add in a little extra beef stock to thin it out if this happens.
Taste your sauce and add seasoning as needed.

Cheese tends to be pretty salty in its own right, so be careful not to just chuck a handful of salt in your sauce right off the bat, or you're going to end up pretty dehydrated after dinner. Take your time and add in little pinches, tasting regularly until you get it exactly where you want it.
Strain the sauce, and throw out the sage leaves and the blue veins of the cheese.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Pat your filet dry with paper towels.
Leftover moisture on your filet will make it steam instead of sear. This is great for a spa day, but not so much for getting a beautiful crust.
Oil your pan, and pre-heat it on high for 1m.
Sear your filet all over, just until it's golden brown.

The point of this step is just to create a crust right on the surface of the filet, not to cook the filet more. Make sure not to leave it in the pan any longer than it takes to get the right texture, or the meat might overcook.
Serve your filet mignon whole or thinly sliced, and drizzle your gorgonzola sauce on top.

If you want some extra points for presentation, we recommend slicing the filet into thin pieces and arranging them nicely on a plate before cheesing it up. If you're feeling fancy and you've got some fresh rosemary lying around, chop it up and sprinkle it on to add some complexity to the flavor and balance out the cheese.

title: Sirloin Steak
subtitle: Reverse Seared with Green Peppercorn Sauce

description.text: Sirloin steak may be a less expensive cut of meat, but that doesn't mean it has to be bland. Keeping the fat layer on while cooking low and slow with MEATER will impart tons of flavor into the meat and keep it tender. To truly elevate your meal, pair your sirloin steak with our green peppercorn sauce inspired by classic elements of French cuisine. This simple and elegant dish will make you feel like a gourmet chef in just a few easy steps!

items.name: Sirloin Steak
items.information:
About 1.5" recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: 2 Tbsp Oil
items.information: Oils with higher smoke point recommended, like avocado or grapeseed oil

items.name: â…” Cup Beef Stock
items.information:
Low-sodium or no-salt stock recommended

Low-sodium vegetable stock can be substituted

meta.text: Pre-heat your oven to <temperature c="120" f="250" />. This may take up to 15m.

While you can trim the fat from the steak if you choose, we recommend not doing this until you're ready to eat, as the fat imparts a lot of flavor and tenderness into the meat during the cooking process.

meta.pro_tip: For steaks 2" or thicker, season the edges as well.

meta.text: Sprinkle a pinch of salt and pepper on both sides, and gently pat the seasoning into your steak.
Insert your MEATER probe into the center of the thickest part of the steak. To ensure proper probe placement, you can use your fingers to feel for the probe.
Place the steak on a roasting rack with a baking tray underneath, then put it in the oven. For easier cleanup, line the tray with aluminum foil.
Using a raised rack allows heat to flow all around the meat, and this results in better color and more even cooking.
Mince your Â½ shallot.
Shallots are commonly used in sauces because their flavor is milder and more refined than other onion types. As they cook, they also release a subtle sweetness.
Wash your parsley with cold water and dry it with a paper towel. Cut off the lower, more fibrous parts of the stems, then finely chop the leaves until you have 1 tbsp.
Parsley is a strong herb with a bit of a peppery flavor, so it works well with this pepper-based sauce. It also adds a nice bit of color to the final product.

meta.pro_tip: We recommend using a stainless steel pan or a cast iron skillet because they'll help your ingredients to brown more easily, and you'll get a lot of nice caramelization in your sauce.

meta.text: If you're using brined peppercorns, they should be rinsed before cooking, but make sure not to crush them. If you're using dry peppercorns, they should be ground, but don't make them too fine. Once the peppercorns are prepared, place your pan on the stove on high heat, then add olive oil (1 tbsp). SautÃ© the shallots and peppercorns for 2-3m until the shallots are golden brown and the peppercorns release a fresh, peppery aroma.

Green peppercorns are the same species as black peppercorns, and the difference is simply that the green peppercorns are harvested before they're fully ripe. When they're picked earlier, the peppercorns have a less pungent and more aromatic flavor. This is ideal for sauces, since the taste of the green peppercorns is less likely to overpower whatever you're pairing with the sauce.

Deglaze the pan with your brandy (â…“ cup). If you're using a gas stove with open flame, remove the pan from the burner while adding alcohol. Scrape any caramelized bits from the sides of the pan and stir them in.

In French cuisine, it's common to find brandy, shallots, mustard, and pepper in recipes together. Deglazing your pan with brandy helps to caramelize your ingredients and add a nice flavor to your sauce, and even though it's strong on its own, it will evaporate during reduction and allow the tastes of the other ingredients to concentrate.

meta.pro_tip: For the best tasting sauce, we recommend making your own no-salt beef stock at home.

meta.text: Pour your beef stock (â…” cup) into the pan.

Liquid is needed when you're reducing a sauce, and beef stock has the added benefit of providing flavor and color. It's also a perfect choice since this sauce goes best with a high-quality steak. Your sauce will become saltier as it reduces, so it's best to use a low-sodium or no-salt stock.
Reduce the heat, then pour your heavy cream (â…” cup) into the pan. Continue stirring the sauce gently for 1m.

Heavy cream will make your sauce creamy without altering the flavor the way that a roux made from flour and butter would. If heavy cream is cooked at a high temperature, it can separate and alter the texture of your sauce, so it's important to turn down the heat before adding the cream.
Stir your mustard (1 tsp) into the sauce.
Dijon mustard will add to the pleasant creamy color of this sauce, and it brings just a hint of pungent spiciness.
Simmer and reduce the sauce just until it's thick enough to coat your spoon or spatula. Keep stirring occasionally to avoid any sauce burning on the edges of the pan.
Remove your pan from the heat, then stir in your chopped parsley.
Taste your sauce, and add as much salt as you'd like to adjust the recipe to your preference.
Carefully take the steak out of the oven using oven mitts, then use tongs to move it to a cutting board or wire rack for resting.

For smaller cuts like steaks, it's absolutely crucial to move the meat to a room temperature surface after taking it out of the cooker. On a hot surface, the carryover cooking phase will last much longer, so your medium rare steak may end up closer to medium. Or even--we're almost too scared to say it--well done.
Remove the MEATER probe using oven mitts.
Pat any extra moisture from the steak with paper towels.
If the surface of the steak is too moist, it will end up steaming rather than searing, and you won't be able to achieve the desired crust on the outside.
Add oil (2 tbsp) to your pan, and pre-heat on high heat until the pan starts to smoke slightly.
Sear the fat edge for 3m until a golden brown crust forms.

If you sear the fat edge before the rest of the steak, it will render into the pan to keep your steak from drying out. If you do want to keep the fat on after cooking, directly searing that edge will make it crispy and succulent.
Sear the sides and fatless edges for 20s each.

It's important to remember that the purpose of this step is just to create a crust right on the surface of the steak, not to cook the steak further. Make sure not to leave the steak in the pan any longer than you need to in order to develop the right texture, or else the meat may end up overcooked.

meta.pro_tip: Using salt flakes and grinding your own peppercorns with a mortar and pestle will give you more flavor and add a little extra crunch to your steak.

meta.text: Season your steak with finishing salt and pepper to taste. We recommend cutting the steak diagonally in Â½" slices, then arranging the slices in a fan shape on your plate. Serve the green peppercorn sauce on the side or drizzle it on top of the steak.

description.text:
Do you ever see two nice-looking people holding hands and you feel like it just makes sense? This recipe is kind of like that. Porcini mushrooms have a distinctly deep and meaty taste that makes them a natural counterpart for beef. And then there's sirloin steak which, when cooked low and slow and then hit with a reverse sear, also becomes insanely flavorful. Together, they're like a match made in Meat Heaven.

When it comes to side dishes for sirloin, we like to keep it simple with roasted vegetables or a good ol' beef and potatoes meal. If you're looking for a perfect beverage pairing, you'll find the best balance with something acidic, like a fruity and full-bodied red wine like cabernet sauvignon, or a citrusy IPA.
