If you sear the fat edge before the rest of the steak, it will render into the pan to keep your steak from drying out. If you do want to keep the fat on after cooking, directly searing that edge will make it crispy and succulent.
Sear the sides and fatless edges for 20s each.

It's important to remember that the purpose of this step is just to create a crust right on the surface of the steak, not to cook the steak further. Make sure not to leave the steak in the pan any longer than you need to in order to develop the right texture, or else the meat may end up overcooked.

We recommend cutting the steak diagonally in Â½" slices, then arranging the slices in a fan shape on your plate. Serve the mushroom sauce on the side or drizzle it on top of the steak, and finish with a sprinkle of rosemary if you'd like to add a bit more flavor.

description.text:
Pulled meats--boy, that's weird to say out loud, isn't it?--are a staple at any barbecue. Everyone loves a good pulled meat sandwich, but what happens when they need a break from pulled pork or chicken, and are clamoring for something different? Lamb shoulder is insanely juicy and delicious when smoked slowly, and it can be shredded just like a classic pork shoulder. In true Texas style, our recipe uses a simple salt and pepper seasoning so you can let the taste of the meat speak for itself.

We won't lie to you, lamb is going to be more expensive than other pulled meats. That's why it's extra important to have the right tools to make sure you'll end up with tender meat and a perfect crust. What are the "right tools"? We're so glad you asked! MEATER will keep you updated with the internal temperature, and can even give you a heads up when to wrap, so you can pull off a pulled lamb that will blow everyone away.

If you're dropping the money on a nice lamb shoulder, chances are you're doing it because you like the flavor, which means you don't want to distract from it with overwhelming sides or sauces. We recommend serving it on Texas toast with a simple side of fresh vegetables or coleslaw. Cold beer is a classic at a barbecue, and a citrusy beer like an IPA will be best for balancing out the flavor of the lamb.

items.name: Lamb Shoulder
items.information:
About 5 lbs recommended

Bone in recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

meta.text: Pre-heat your smoker to <temperature c="120" f="250" />. This can take up to 15m.

Low and slow cooking keeps more moisture in the meat, which is especially important since you'll be removing the fat from the top of your lamb. A longer cooking time is also the key to a nice and crispy bark on the outside of the meat.
Trim the fat and silverskin from the top of your lamb.

Obviously you need some fat in the meat if you want to end up with really succulent lamb. The trouble is, when you've got a super chunky layer like the one you see on top of the lamb shoulder, the fat isn't actually going to render while you're cooking. Trimming off this extra fat and getting rid of the silverskin also makes it easier for the smoky flavor to get into the meat. We assume that's what you're going for since you're using a smoker.

meta.pro_tip: If you'd like your crust even crispier on your next cook, you can season the lamb shoulder 24h before cooking, then leave it uncovered in the fridge to dry brine.

meta.text: Sprinkle salt and pepper all over, and pat it in.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the lamb shoulder.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the black ceramic handle, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Set the lamb top side up in the smoker.

Lamb placement is largely a matter of personal preference, and there are benefits to cooking both top side up and bottom side up. We've found that keeping the fatty side of the lamb shoulder at the top while cooking gives us a much better color and crust.
Turn up your smoker to <temperature c="135" f="275" />.

Unlike some of our other smoked recipes, we don't recommend wrapping the lamb when you turn up the heat. We want the lamb shoulder to develop a nice and crispy crust, so it's best to avoid steaming it or letting it cook in the juices. Lamb fat also tends to have a strong smell, and leaving the meat unwrapped will help the fat to either cook or drip out so your lamb doesn't end up getting all self-conscious about it.
Loosely wrap the lamb in foil with the probe poking out, and let it rest covered for 30m-1h.

The longer you give your lamb shoulder to rest, the more time the juices will have to redistribute throughout the meat. Because bigger cuts need a longer resting time, wrapping your lamb in foil and covering it with a towel helps to retain heat. Just make sure not to rest for longer than an hour or it'll get cold.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts, and unwrap your lamb.
Throw away the bones and cartilage from your lamb.
Okay, we know we literally just said to throw away any cartilage you find, but we also won't judge you if you want to eat it.
Shred the lamb into thin strands with shredding claws or two large forks.

title: Pulled Pork
subtitle: Smoked with Apple Juice and Vinegar

description.text:
If you're panicking because you accidentally invited way too many people to your barbecue, this recipe is for you. It keeps well at warm temperatures and feeds a lot of people, so it's perfect for big get-togethers. Plus, if you pick up some rolls, you can put together little sandwiches and make everyone think this was way more planned out.

Even though pulled pork is hard to mess up, it's still important to cook it properly so that the meat doesn't dry out. Not only will MEATER let you know when your pork is at its juiciest and most shreddable, but you can also set custom alerts to remind you to wrap it, which means you can focus all of your attention on party prep.

Pulled pork can be served with any of your favorite barbecue sides, so have fun creating your own personalized barbecue platter. Personally, we like fresh coleslaw to offset the heaviness of the pork, and cornbread to go with the sweetness of the apple flavors. When it comes to drinks, there's nothing like cracking open a cold beer at a barbecue, and bitter varieties like IPA will balance out the sweet taste of the pork.

items.name: Pork Butt
items.information:
10-11 lbs recommended

Bone in recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: Olive Oil
items.information: Just enough to lightly coat the pork

meta.pro_tip: If you can use applewood pellets, these will complement the apple juice and apple cider vinegar, as well as add a little bit of sweetness.

meta.text: Pre-heat your smoker to <temperature c="120" f="250" />. This can take up to 15m.

Low and slow cooking keeps more moisture in the meat, which is especially important since you'll be removing the thick fat from your pork butt. A longer cooking time is also the key to a nice and crispy bark on the outside of the meat.
Combine your dry ingredients.

Dry rubs are best for pork butt because they caramelize and create a crust as the pork cooks, which means more flavor and more color. For this recipe, we went with classic seasonings for a sweet and smoky pulled pork. Our unique contribution is celery salt, which works with the garlic and onion powders to give the pork a slightly fresh taste so you can feel good about eating your vegetables while loading up on starchy side dishes. Since pork doesn't absorb as much smoke as as other proteins like beef, we also cheated a little bit and opted for smoked paprika.
Stir your vinegar (2 tbsp) into the apple juice.

It's pretty common practice to spritz pork butt with apple cider vinegar, because it gives the meat moisture and adds a slight tangy flavor. Mixing in apple juice makes the pork sweeter, and the sugar content in the juice helps to form the crust on the surface.
Pour your apple juice (1 cup) into a bowl.
Trim any thick fat from the surface of your pork butt.

Obviously you need some fat in the meat if you want to end up with really succulent pulled pork. The trouble is, when you've got a super chunky layer like the ones you see on the outside of a lot of pork butts, the fat isn't actually going to render while you're cooking. Trimming off this extra fat also makes it easier for the smoky flavor to get into the meat. We assume that's what you're going for since you're using a smoker.
Pat your entire pork butt dry with paper towels.

You should always pat your meat dry so your oil and seasonings will stick better. If you bought your pork butt pre-packaged at a grocery store, this also gets rid of any leftover liquid from the packaging.

meta.pro_tip: If you want to try something a little different on your next cook, a pretty common practice among barbecuers is to use yellow mustard instead of oil. It's less expensive, and it creates a really nice, thick bark on the surface of the pork. You also don't have to worry about changing the taste of the meat because the mustard loses flavor while it sits in the smoker.

meta.text: Coat the pork butt with your olive oil.

The spices may bring the flavor, but oil is what brings them all together and makes them work. Not only does it bind the rub to the meat, it also conducts heat to the surface of the meat to crisp it up.
Sprinkle your rub all over and pat it in.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the pork butt.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the black ceramic handle, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Set your MEATER charger close to the smoker.

If you're using MEATER Plus or MEATER Block, the charging dock needs to stay as close to your cooker as possible so it can stay connected to the probe. From there, it'll boost the signal over Bluetooth or WiFi, depending on your model. If you're using the original MEATER, the charger won't have any repeater function, so you'll just want to keep your smart device close to the probe.
Set the pork top side up in the smoker.

Pork placement is largely a matter of personal preference, and there are benefits to cooking both top side up and bottom side up. We like to keep the fatty side of the pork butt at the top while cooking so that the fat can soak into the meat. Otherwise, most of it will drip off, and we just feel like that's a tragedy.
Put the pork in a dish and pour your cider mix around it.

The main drawback of spritzing meat is having to open the smoker over and over, because even a teensy peek can slow the cook down quite a bit. Letting the pork marinate in the vinegar mixture eliminates this problem. Just be careful not to pour the mixture directly on the pork so it doesn't make the crust all soggy. (Bonus points if you can count how many times we say "crust" in this recipe.)
Loosely cover the dish with foil, poke out the probe, and pop it back in the smoker.
If you can, leave some room between the foil and the top of the pork. This allows space for steam to circulate all around the meat, and stops the foil from scratching any of the rub off.
Let your pork rest covered for 30m-1h.

The longer you give your pork butt to rest, the more time the juices will have to redistribute throughout the meat. Because bigger cuts need a longer resting time, wrapping your pork in foil and covering it with a towel helps to retain heat. Just make sure not to rest for longer than an hour or it'll get cold.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Unwrap your pork butt, and throw away the bone and cartilage.
Okay, we know we literally just said to throw away any cartilage you find, but we also won't judge you if you want to eat it.
Shred the pork into thin strands with shredding claws or two large forks.

It's not a barbecue without getting a little messy. For an extra drippy and delectable pulled pork meal, drizzle it with the apple cider mixture from the tray, or top it with the sauce of your choice. Serve your pork with classic BBQ sides like coleslaw or cornbread, and pair it with a crisp beer.

title: Beef and Pork Meatloaf
subtitle: Slow Roasted and Glazed with BBQ Sauce

description.text:
To many people, the word "meatloaf" immediately conjures memories of a home-cooked meal prepared by the loving hands of a mother, grandmother, or other maternal figure. While a well-crafted meatloaf evokes feelings of warmth and familiarity, it seems uncommon to find those same feelings when ordering meatloaf at a restaurant. To truly capture the magic of a meatloaf, it's best made in the home. Luckily, that's very easy to do.

Even though meatloaf (or some version of it) has endured for centuries in different parts of the world, it has traditionally been most popular during times of hardship as a way to stretch protein and make the most of leftovers. For this reason, meatloaf is extremely versatile, and can be made with any meats and flavorings the chef desires. The only undisputed rule is that it must be cooked to perfection to produce a soft and succulent result, so it's a good thing you've got MEATER on your side!

A classic, homey dish like this one deserves comforting sides to match, so we suggest serving it alongside some creamy mashed potatoes, and some cooked vegetables like green beans or asparagus.

items.name: 1Â½ Lb Ground Beef
items.information:
At least 10% fat recommended

Should not be frozen when starting cook

items.name: Â½ Lb Ground Pork
items.information: Should not be frozen when starting cook

items.name: Â½ Cup Bread Crumbs
items.information:
Can be homemade or pre-packaged

Panko bread crumbs can be used

meta.text: Pre-heat your oven to <temperature c="150" f="300" />. This may take up to 15m.

Since our recipe uses ground meat with a little bit of fat content, we recommend taking it slow and not cranking up the oven temperature. The fat will have time to properly render, and your meatloaf will be much juicier.
Mince your onion until you have 3 tbsp.

It wouldn't be a proper meatloaf without onion. We chose white onion because not only is it one of the more pungent and flavorful varieties, it will also speckle your meatloaf with a beautiful golden color when cooked, as opposed to red onions or shallots which turn more of a dingy brown. Your onions should be minced as finely as possible so that if a few pieces come out while slicing, it won't compromise the structural integrity of the whole loaf. It's better to avoid load-bearing onion chunks.
Crack an egg into a mixing bowl large enough to fit all of your ingredients. Beat the egg gently until the white and yolk are completely combined.

You'll find eggs in almost every recipe for meatloaf or meatballs, primarily because they help to bind the meat together and keep it in a stable form. This is especially important for our recipe since the loaf doesn't stay in the pan throughout the cooking process. As a bonus, eggs also add richness and protein to the meat.
Pour your milk (1 cup) into the bowl and whisk it into the egg.

Aside from those with an acquired taste for milk steak, few people would think of combining milk with beef. However, we've found that adding milk to this recipe makes your meatloaf softer and more tender.

meta.pro_tip: You can use fresh sausages without casing in place of the ground meat. Just keep in mind that these will likely already have seasoning, so make sure you're choosing a flavor that you'd like in your meatloaf.

meta.text: Add your ground beef (1Â½ lb) and ground pork (Â½ lb) to the bowl.

The main goal with this recipe was to avoid the stereotypical dry meatloaf that too many people are used to. For this reason, in addition to recommending ground beef with a minimum of 10% fat content, we also included ground pork for additional fat to make the meat succulent and flavorful.
Add the chopped onion into the bowl.
Pour your bread crumbs (Â½ cup) in with the other ingredients.

Bread crumbs help the egg to hold the meatloaf together by soaking up the juices of the meat, which keeps them from simply leaking out. This also gives your meatloaf a hint of a fluffy texture. You'll get the best color and texture if you're able to make your own bread crumbs at home. Simply bake a loaf of fresh bread for 15-20m, then cut it into pieces and run it through a food processor.
Season the ingredients with your paprika (1 tbsp), nutmeg (1 tsp), and salt (2 tsp).

Paprika is another common ingredient in meatloaf, but we wanted to put an extra spin on it with the added smoky flavor. While nutmeg is less frequently found in meatloaf recipes, it's known to enhance and round out the taste of savory meat dishes, especially sausages. With this aromatic blend of spices, your meatloaf will be anything but bland.
Gently knead the contents of the bowl until all of the ingredients are fully blended.

meta.pro_tip: If you don't have a mold, you can simply shape the meat into a cylindrical shape with your hands. You can even use a long knife to flatten the sides and mimic the classic pan shape.

meta.text: Use your loaf pan to mold the mixture into your desired shape, then turn out the loaf onto a sheet of parchment paper.

We may not be able to solve the age-old mystery of who decided to put ground meat in a brick shape in the first place, but we can at least make it less of a hassle. Not only is it simpler to insert a probe in meat that's not in a pan, turning out the loaf after shaping also reduces the risk of overcooking since the meat won't be resting in a hot dish. In addition, cooking out of the pan makes the loaf easier to slice without digging or turning the sauce side down. Not to mention that more uncovered meat means more sauce!
Insert your MEATER probe into the center of the thickest part of the loaf. For the most accurate temperature reading, the ground meat should be as tightly packed as possible.
Keeping the meatloaf on the parchment paper, place it on a baking tray and put it in the oven. You can also put the paper directly on the oven rack if you prefer.
Move the meatloaf to a cutting board or wire rack for resting.
Remove the MEATER probe using oven mitts.
Increase your oven temperature to <temperature c="220" f="430" />. If you have the option, turn on the grill setting.
You'll get the best color and texture by allowing your BBQ sauce to caramelize at a high temperature for just a few minutes.
Brush the top and edges of the meatloaf with a generous amount of your BBQ sauce (4 tbsp).
Place your meatloaf back in the oven for just about 10m.
Take your meatloaf back out of the oven, and put it on a cutting board to serve.
Since the second portion of the cook is so brief, only the sauce will end up cooking rather than the meat itself, and it isn't necessary to have a second resting phase.
Cut your meatloaf into slices no thinner than Â½", and serve with extra BBQ sauce on the side.

To truly evoke that familiar, homey feeling, this meatloaf is best served with other hot comfort foods. Of course, meatloaf and mashed potatoes are a classic combination, and you can round this out with cooked vegetables like green beans or asparagus.

description.text:
We know there are some people out there who might be hesitant to try sirloin steak because it's a bit on the leaner side, compared to a cut like rib-eye with a lot of marbling. If this is you, we've got a couple of things that might ease your mind. First, as long as you're cooking low and slow with MEATER, the distinctive fat layer on the side will melt into the meat and inject it with bigtime beefy flavor. Second, if the melty fat doesn't convince you, you'll get to finish this recipe by plopping on some garlic butter on there and basically counteracting the leanness of the meat. On top of being a blend of garlic and butter, which is already a major selling point, we've also thrown in some of our favorite herbs and a little squeeze of lemon juice for our own special flair.

When it comes to side dishes for sirloin, we like to keep it simple with roasted vegetables or a good ol' beef and potatoes meal. You can also find a variety of mouth-watering sauces in our recipe menu if you want to add some flair to your sirloin. If you're looking for a perfect beverage pairing, you'll find the best balance with something acidic, like a fruity and full-bodied cabernet sauvignon or Bordeaux, or a citrusy IPA.

items.name: Sirloin Steak
items.information:
About 1.5" thick recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: Oil
items.information:
Just enough to lightly coat the pan

Oils with higher smoke point recommended, like avocado or grapeseed oil

meta.pro_tip: If you have the time, we recommend leaving your butter out for 2 hours to soften before mixing in the other ingredients. You can microwave it in a pinch, but be careful not to completely melt it.

meta.text: Dice your butter (1 cup) into 1" squares.
If you've only got salted butter in your fridge, don't worry, we won't tell on you. We only recommend unsalted butter so that there's less risk of going overboard when you add salt later.
Cut off the stems and finely chop the leaves (1 tbsp).

Parsley is one of the strongest herbs, so we chose it to add a powerful peppery flavor to our butter. While you can experiment with using different herbs to your taste, we recommend parsley because its leafy texture won't disturb the smoothness of your butter like some more needly herbs. Parsley also adds a pop of bright color, and it makes your butter healthier. That's what we tell ourselves, anyway.
Thinly slice your chives until you have 2 tsp.

Chives give your butter a nice onion taste without overpowering the other flavors, and they work well with the parsley to make your butter more colorful. We also recommend chives over other onion varieties because they won't make the butter quite as chunky.
Peel and mince your garlic (4 cloves).

Ah, garlic. An ingredient so delicious and versatile that it has its own butter. We wanted this recipe to be customizable, so if you're like us and are never satisfied with the suggested garlic amount in recipes, you can feel free to go nuts.
Squeeze your lemon juice (2 tbsp, or about half of a medium-sized lemon) into the bowl.

Other garlic butters may include herbs and onions like ours, but lemon juice is our own special twist on the recipe (please pardon the pun). The acidity adds a contrast to the other flavors to give the butter more complexity, and the liquid element makes it easier to mix the ingredients together.
Sprinkle your white pepper (2 tsp) and salt to taste into the butter.

We chose white pepper both because the earthy flavor complements the herbs in the butter, and because it just looks less speckly in lighter sauces. With the salt, we recommend using flakes for better flavor, for a nice little crunch, and because it's easier to control the amount so you don't overdo it.
Stir the butter well. Taste it and add seasoning as needed.
Roll your butter into a cylinder in a sheet of parchment paper, and twist the ends closed.
Place your butter roll in the freezer for 20m to set.

Rolling and chilling your butter helps you cut clean, circular pats to give your food a more professional presentation. If you have any left over, you can keep it wrapped and leave it in the freezer, and it will keep for a long time. If you're too anxious to taste that garlicky goodness and don't want to wait, you can use a melon baller to scoop out cute lil' butter balls.
Pre-heat your oven to <temperature c="120" f="250" />. This can take up to 15m.

You might be tempted to trim off the thick layer of fat on the side of your steak, but we urge you to back away from the knife. This isn't to say you can't trim the fat, but we recommend not doing this until you're ready to eat. Since sirloin is a leaner cut, it has a reputation for being tough and chewy, but leaving the fat on will impart a lot of flavor and tenderness into the meat during the cook.
Sprinkle salt and pepper all over, and pat it in.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the steak.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the black ceramic handle, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Place the steak on a rack and pop it in the oven.

Raised racks let heat flow all around the meat, which means better color and more even cooking. A foil-lined tray under the rack will seriously improve your life when it's time to clean up the kitchen. High five, past self.
Let your steak rest on a cutting board.

Carryover cooking lasts a lot longer on a hot surface, so smaller cuts like this one need to be moved to a room temperature surface after you take them off of heat. If not, your medium rare steak may be closer to medium, or your well done steak may be closer to shoe leather.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Pat your steak dry with paper towels.
Leftover moisture on your steak will make it steam instead of sear. This is great for a spa day, but not so much for getting a beautiful crust.
Oil your pan, and pre-heat it on high for 1m.
Sear the fat edge until a golden crust forms.

Remember when we talked about leaving the fat on the steak while you're cooking? You're about to find out why! If you sear the fat edge before the rest of the steak, it renders into the pan to keep your steak juicy. If you do want to eat it with the fat on, directly searing that edge will make it an extra crispy treat.
Sear the rest of the steak just until it's golden brown.

The point of this step is just to create a crust right on the surface of the steak, not to cook the steak more. Make sure not to leave it in the pan any longer than it takes to get the right texture, or the meat might overcook.
Serve your sirloin whole or sliced. Top it with a Â½" pat of garlic butter, and allow the butter a few seconds to start melting before serving.
If you want some extra points for presentation, we recommend slicing the steak into Â½" pieces and arranging them nicely on a plate before adding all of that buttery amazingness.

title: Salmon Fillet
subtitle: Smoked with Sweet and Spicy Rub

description.text:
Finally, you can put an end to the conflict between eating healthy and fulfilling your passion for barbecue! Along with being a powerhouse of health benefits, salmon is super quick and easy to cook. It's tasty on its own or with a squeeze of lemon, but our recipe will make it sweet and smoky with just the teensiest bit of a kick. Either way, you get to pat yourself on the back for making such good choices. We're proud of you.

Even low and slow smoking doesn't take very long with salmon, so it can be easy to overcook and dry out. Lucky for you, you've got MEATER to tell you when your fish is at its peak flaky deliciousness.

So you've got yourself a healthy protein, why not go all out and fix yourself a whole nutritious meal? Brown rice and fresh greens are easy side dishes, and will make you feel better about indulging with an elegant beverage. Speaking of which, salmon is usually coupled with white wine, specifically sweet or sparkling whites if the salmon is smoked.

items.name: Salmon Fillet
items.information:
About 1Â½ lb recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

meta.pro_tip: We like our fish a little bit on the sweeter side, so we prefer to smoke it with apple or cherry pellets.

meta.text: Pre-heat your smoker to <temperature c="105" f="220" />. Turn on the Super Smoke setting if you have the option.
Feel the salmon flesh and pull out any bones.
Even if you bought your fish deboned, there's still a chance of sneaky bones left behind.
Combine your dry ingredients.

Since we're going for a sweeter flavor with this recipe, we made our rub with a base of brown sugar. Of course, we also enjoy a kick, so we added just enough chili powder to put some extra pep in our step.
Put your salmon skin side down on a sheet of parchment.
Parchment paper makes it easier to move your salmon in and out of the smoker, and saves you from the shame of having to scrape fish chunks off of the smoker grates.

meta.pro_tip: If you'd like your salmon even more flavorful on your next cook, you can put your rub on the fish up to 6h before cooking, then leave it uncovered in the fridge to cure. Make sure to set a small amount of the rub aside so that you can add a little bit more seasoning after curing.

meta.text: Sprinkle your rub on the flesh side and pat it in.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the fillet.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the black ceramic, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Set your MEATER charger close to the smoker.

If you're using MEATER Plus or MEATER Block, the charging dock needs to stay as close to your cooker as possible so it can stay connected to the probe. From there, it'll boost the signal over Bluetooth or WiFi, depending on your model. If you're using the original MEATER, the charger won't have any repeater function, so you'll just want to keep your smart device close to the probe.
Pop the salmon in the smoker.
Let your salmon rest on a cutting board.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.

Before serving, you can use a spatula to gently move the salmon off of the parchment for a cleaner presentation. If you're just too ready to dig in (totally understandable), the salmon can be served while still on the paper.
Slice your salmon fillet into smaller steaks to serve.
Build yourself a nice, healthy meal with some rice and veggies on the side, and then toast to your good health with a sweet or sparkling white wine.

description.text:
Even if you love cooking, you're going to have some days when you just can't be bothered. But don't break out the TV dinners yet, because we've got a solution for exactly those days. Pork chops are quick to cook, and this recipe uses a basic seasoning blend gets your pork from the fridge to the oven to your plate in no time without sacrificing the flavor. And they're inexpensive to boot!

Since pork is at its crackliest when you cook it at a high temperature, you'll want to make sure it doesn't dry out. That's why it's especially handy to use MEATER to alert you at the perfect internal temperature, and keep you from losing any delectable juiciness.

Pork chops go well with classic mashed potatoes, or sweeter sides like applesauce. Refreshing beverages are the best option so you don't overpower your pork, so reach for a crisp cider or pinot noir.

items.name: 2 Pork Chops
items.information:
About 1Â½ lb each recommended

Bone in and skin off recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: Oil
items.information:
Just enough to lightly coat the pork

Olive oil recommended for flavor

meta.text: Pre-heat your oven to <temperature c="220" f="425" />. This can take up to 15m.

Cooking pork at a higher temperature gives it a nice golden color, and it makes the fat crispy and delicious. As a bonus, it makes the cook time shorter so you won't be staring at the oven all evening waiting for your dinner.
Combine your dry ingredients.

Salt, pepper, and garlic powder are pretty standard seasonings for a pork chop. Of course, we're big fans of putting our own unique spins on the classics, so we decided to throw some paprika in the mix to add some smokiness.
Pat your pork chops dry with paper towels.

You should always pat your meat dry so your oil and seasonings will stick better. If you bought your pork pre-packaged at a grocery store, this also gets rid of any leftover liquid from the packaging.
Coat the pork chops with your oil.

The spices may bring the flavor, but oil is what brings them all together and makes them work. Not only does it bind the rub to the meat, it also conducts heat to the surface of the meat to crisp it up.
Sprinkle your rub all over and pat it in.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the pork chop.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the black ceramic handle, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Set your MEATER charger close to the oven.

If you're using MEATER Plus or MEATER Block, the charging dock needs to stay as close to your cooker as possible so it can stay connected to the probe. From there, it'll boost the signal over Bluetooth or WiFi, depending on your model. If you're using the original MEATER, the charger won't have any repeater function, so you'll just want to keep your smart device close to the probe.
Place the pork on a rack and stick it in the oven.

Raised racks let heat flow all around the meat, which means better color and more even cooking. A foil-lined tray under the rack will seriously improve your life when it's time to clean up the kitchen. High five, past self.
Let your pork chops rest on a cutting board.

Carryover cooking lasts a lot longer on a hot surface, so smaller cuts like these ones need to be moved to a room temperature surface after you take them off of heat. If not, your beautiful pork chops may end up closer to pork jerky.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Serve your pork chops whole with the bone on.

Pork goes well with a lot of side dishes, but we like classic mashed potatoes or applesauce the best. If you'd like a nice beverage to go with them, reach for something nice and refreshing, like cider or white wine.

description.text: Gremolata is an Italian condiment that traditionally is dry sprinkled on top of slow-braised meat!

items.name: 1 Bunch (1/2 Cup) Parsley
items.information: Italian flat leaf parsley recommended to be chopped

items.name: 1/3 Cup (5/6 Tbsp) Extra Virgin Olive Oil
items.information: Regular Olive Oil can be used

items.name: Salt to taste
items.information: Himalayan or Maldon salt flakes recommended.

meta.text: Using the hand peeler, peel the skin of 1Lemon make long strip peels, it will be easy to chop later do it lightly, being careful not to remove too much of the white pith which has a very bitter taste!

If you want the strongest and most even lemon flavor in your food, zesting with a knife is the best way to do it Vegetable peeler or microplane could do the job but I prefer with knife, gives different texture in fact

meta.pro_tip: You can remove white part from each peels if you want your sauce not to get the bitter flavour in it. Work closely with the tip of the knife.

meta.text: Using a sharp knife cut thin strips then thinely chop or dice chop and add in to the bowl
Finely work your mince, you don't want your sauce to have chunky pieces in it
Using a sharp knife peel and mince your garlic (1 clove). Mince and add to the bowl
Wash your parsley (1 bunch) with cold water and dry it with a paper towel. Cut off the lower, more fibrous parts of the stems, then finely chop the leaves. Chop and add to the bowl!

Parsley is one of the most versatile herbs available, and can be used in a large variety of dishes. We recommend using Italian flat leaf parsley over curly parsley because it has a much more bold and intense flavor. When selecting parsley, you can rub a little bit in your hands, then smell your hands to make sure it has a strong aroma.
Add your olive oil. 1/3Cup (5/6 Tbsp). The amount used is enough to get level and coat the herbs.
Though we caution against using extra virgin olive oil over heat due to its low smoke point, it's ideal for cold sauces like this one because of its more pungent flavor.
Squeeze half of a lemon (about 1 to 2 tbsp) into the bowl.
Lemon juice adds acidity and tanginess to balance out the powerful earthy flavors of the parsley and garlic.
Season your sauce with salt and pepper to taste.

Using salt flakes and freshly ground peppercorns will make the flavor stand out, as well as give you some added crunch. Salt flakes also give you more control over how much you're putting in so you don't overdo it.
Mix the ingredients together and taste. Your sauce can be served right away, though we recommend covering it with plastic cling wrap and refrigerating it for at least an hour.
Resting in the fridge allows the flavors to fully combine for a more flavorful sauce, and laying plastic cling wrap right on top of the sauce also helps to prevent oxidation and preserve the color.

meta.pro_tip: If possible, we suggest using all of the sauce within 24h. Beyond that, it may start to lose its vivid green color due to the acidity of the lemon

meta.text: Serve drizzling all over your favourite protein, use as much you want it can go literally on EVERYTHING. Meat , fish, soups,salads, eggs give brightness and colours to your meal!

description.text: The biggest complaint when smoking pork ribs or more specifically St. Louis-style pork spare ribs most people have is that they turn out dry and tough. The 3-2-1 method, so named for the three sets of cooking time ,for smoking ribs nearly guarantees tender, fall-off-the-bone ribs without a lot of extra effort. St. Louis-style ribs are cut from close to the belly of the pig, and have the tips removed. This makes for a very clean rectangular shape that cooks evenly. St. Louis-style spare ribs are usually ready for a rub and to head to the smoker as soon as you bring them home. The smell of that smoked meat and the taste dispelled by that spice mix will spread all over the place and make your neighbors jump off the fence [to taste]!

items.name: 1 Pork Rib
items.information: St. Louis style spareribs is great quality for smoking, also can be used Baby pork ribs

items.name: 2 Tsp Cayenne Pepper
items.information: Added to the meat on the grill helps tenderize and add flavour

items.name: 1 Cup Apple Juice
items.information: I like to fill a spritz bottle with (2 Cups) apple juice and spritzle generously the top of the ribs with apple juice.

items.name: 1/2 Cup BBQ Sauce
items.information: 1/2 Cup for glazing the meat in the final stage. Cook for 1h with sauce.

items.name: A spritz bottle
items.information: A spritz is simply a spray bottle with liquid for spritzing

meta.pro_tip: if you use mustards seeds don't forget to polverize them! use a mortar & pastle. Is important that you crush them if you want them to release more flavour and to be mixed well with the rest of the powders. You can use a meat tenderizer to crush as well.

meta.text: Combine the following ingredients in a bowl: 1/2 Cup Brown sugar, 2 Tbsp Onion powder, 2 Tbsp Smoked paprika, 2 Tbsp Garlic powder, 1 Tbsp Salt, 1 Tbsp Black pepper, 1 Tbsp Dry Mustard, 2 Tsp Cayenne pepper, 1 Tsp Allspice
A dry rub is a combination of spices, herbs, and sugar. All this dry and spice ingredients mixed together used for coating and flavoring meat.
Ignite and pre-heat the wood pellet smoker to a low temperature (105Â°C) - with Supersmoke option if available!
Pat meat dry as you want to insure no liquids from packaging or blood residues stay on the meat before seasoning.

meta.pro_tip: Remove silverskin with kitchen paper ( use to increase grip for pulling ). And butter knife / spoon to get started from one bone

meta.text: Clean each bone (back side of the rack) from silverskin. Get started from one bone, slip a butter knife or spoon handle under it and try to get enough pulled up so you can grab it with paper towel and remove interely. You will notice a thick plastic like skin covering meat and bones ;if you have trouble grasping it with your bare hands don't forget to use a paper towel for better grip

Make sure that the membrane, or silverskin, covering the bone side of each rack gets removed. If left on, it keeps seasonings and smoke from penetrating the meat. The rib would also shrink when silverskin is not been removed.
Sprinkle generously back and front of the spareribs with your dry mix, then rub.
Sprinkle the dry rub onto the meat. Using your hands, rub the spices onto the meat. Rub over the surface like you are trying to rub cream into your own skin.

meta.pro_tip: Select the area that has more meat and less bones. Place the probe as far you can from bones to not alterate temperature reading. Hitting the fat of meat with mid probe sensor could also alterate temperature reading.

meta.text: Insert into the thickest part of the meat with the internal sensor in the center. If ensure use your finger to check probe placement. Try keep the probe as much distant you can from the bones.
Place the spareribs top side up in to the grill shelf, the probe head should face the front of the grill where the temperature is generally higher Cook with supersmoke for the first 3 hours

Three hours is the perfect time to smoke this pork cut! give the right amound of smokiness the the ribs in the initial fase of the cooking is very important. We aim for a nice smoke ring at this point.

steps.title: Spritzle and wrap meat in Foil

overlay_text.text: Wrap in foil or butcher paper

meta.text: RFH after the first 3hs. Wearing oven mitts or using a  spatula remove the meat from the grill and place on a sheet of aluminium foil / or butcher papaer spritzle with apple juice generously to cover fold and wrap the meat seal well but do it without squeezing the foil too much. ensure probe protudes from the foil and the sensor is not covered!
Carefully maybe hot! I usually get my foil pre-cut and ready ahead of time about 30 inches long and 18 inches wide.
Return the meat in the smoker and keep cooking for the next 2h. get the heat inside of a closed space so they can steam and get really tender.
Maintain same grilling temperature, stop supersmoke option at this point the smoke will stop penetrate in the meat.
After cooking for approsimatevely 2 hours wrapped in foil the meat should heat the target of 95Â°C , using oven mitts remove from heat and unwrap them from the foil and get ready for finishing up.
Increase smoker temperature to 150Â°C (300Â°F)
Brush now top side of the rack with a thick layer of (1/2 Cup) BBQ sauce.
This is when the bark is finalized and it's also a great time to add some sauce if you like them that way. A higher temperature will also help color and caramelize the sugars in the sauce
Using a pair of tongs move the rack on a cutting board for resting.
Do it carefully , meat is cookerd fall apart
Remove the MEATER probe using oven mitts.

St. Louis style spareribs are cooked to perfection, if you try to lift one edge of the rack should bend without breaking , all you need is to cut between each rib bone and arrange on a plate serve with a nice coselow salad , barbecue sauce and lots of napkins!

description.text: Magret is the juicy breast of a Moulard duck, typically raised cage-free, in open barns and on a vegetarian grain diet. In France is exclusively used for the production of â€œFoie Grasâ€ Magret can cooks up much like a steak; itâ€™s a perfect weeknight meal or special occasion dinner, and it's one of our favourite tasty recipes. Learn how to cook this delicious duck breast with Balsamic and Honey reduction sauce.

items.name: Salt to taste
items.information: Table salt can be used. Salt flakes recommended (Maldon or Himalayan).

items.name: Pepper to taste
items.information: Ground black pepper can be used. Freshly ground recommended for more flavour.

meta.text: Pre-heat oven to 120Â°C fan on. Cooking low and slow provides more control of the internal temperature, a stunning browned crust, and a more tender Duck breast.

meta.pro_tip: For better and easier scoring, keep the meat well chilled and carve the fat when it is well solidified. You can leave the breast in the freezer for 15mn, this will work very well also!

meta.text: Score the skin in a cross hatch pattern roughly 1/2 in diamonds being careful to only score the skin and not to cut through the flesh. Scoring duck breasts aids the release (or 'rendering') of the layer of fat.

Trim up duck breast remove veins and excess fat from the side of the meat. Lift and remove the small fillet as it will be cooked sooner and may separate from the breast during preparation. Keep aside or cook separately.
Seasoning both side of the breast with salt to taste(1Tsp) and pepper to taste (1/2 Tsp)
Place the pan on a appropriately size stove hob (stove top US) on medium heat. It can take up to 2 -3 minutes to be ready.
feel the pan

Try leaving the duck alone on the skin for 5 minutes, you will have to give it a peek to make sure it doesn't burn; the layer of fat will continue melting until take a crunchy golden color, evenly distributed.
For this step No oil is required. The fat from the duck is sufficient
flip over the duck allow a quick sear (20 sec) to the meat side and his edges while using a Tbsp to collect fats and sprinkle them on the top breast
You can tilt the pan and sprinkle / pour the rendered fats, this will enrich the flavors and help color the scored breast evenly.
Turn off the heat and remove the meat! put the meat aside on a plate or on the same cutting board
Carefully poor fats in to a bowl/container we will use 2Tbsp of those to create a tasty sauce in the same pan
the pan no need to be cleaned, all meat flavours are in there!
Insert into the thickest part of the breast(s) with the internal sensor in the center. If unsure use your finger to check your probe placement.
Using tongs place the meat on the rack, ensure to have a baking tray underneed to contain cooking juices.
Place the Duck inside oven
Using a kitchen knife, finely chop a small shallot (2 Tbsp,use 1/2 if is a regular)
Shallots with Duck because they have a delicate and sweet flavor with a hint of sharpness that complement well this sauce.
Return pan on the stove hob on medium high heat. Browning shallot with 2Tbsp of duck fat for the next two minutes.
Poor 3Tbsp of Balsamic vinegar and1Tbsp of Honey. Give a quick stir with a wooden spoon or whisk. This is a quick operation before adding the rest of liquid engredients
Poor (6-7 Tbsp) 1/3Cup of Chicken broth in to the pan. Can be use cold or hot stock. it's a small quantity will not make any difference!

meta.pro_tip: When you reduce a broth check the saltiness by testing your preparation. You can balance saltness and reduce the level of salt by adding a bit of water.

meta.text: Simmer and reduce by half. Reduce to half on the same heat, will take approximately 3mins. Stir with a spoon or whisk time to time!

ingredients: 1/2 of a knob of cold butter (1 Tbsp)

meta.text: Lower the heat and add 1/2 of a knob of cold butter (1 Tbsp) and whisk vigorously for a minute
Incorporating cold butter to the hot liquid will help emulsified, is the process to thickness your preparation and give velvety sensation in to it.

Taste the level of saltness and thickness correct with salt if needed or add another Tbsp of butter if the sauce is not thick enough. By adding butter you also give sweetness in case the reduced sauce is lightly salty

meta.pro_tip: the solid part it's a yummy chutney do not waste it, delitious on bread toasts for example.

meta.text: Using a kitchen sieve and a small bowl placed underneath, strain the ready sauce. Discard the solid part or keep and use as chutney is your choice!. Taste the flavor, if necessary add a pinch of salt. Keep aside for final presentation(serving)
Use oven mitts to remove Duck breast from heat. Rest on a wooden cutting board using tongs to move the meat.
Use oven mitts; be careful as the end of the probe may be hot.

If you want an eye-catching fan-shaped presentation, slice the breast diagonally (1/2 inch thick) and arrange on the plate with the fat side facing up. Finish by presenting the sliced breast with a generous dose of balsamic reduction to cover it

description.text:
So let's say you're a smoking pro, and you're looking for a recipe to shake things up between briskets. Or maybe you're hosting a party for people who both love barbecue and own yachts, and you need to cook something impressive. In either case, smoked duck breast should meet your needs pretty nicely.

Of course you never want to mess up when cooking your food, but it's especially important to get it right when you're cooking something fancy like duck. When it's overcooked, duck meat can end up really tough. But properly-cooked duck will be tender on the inside with gorgeous, deep red skin and crispy fat, and MEATER will help you calculate the perfect cook time to make that happen!

If you're going to indulge with your main course, why not do the same with your sides? Duck breast should be paired with a decadent French side dish, particularly something cheesy like potatoes au gratin.

As much as we love cooking for special occasions, we can't forget about the everyday cooks. At the end of a long day, the last thing you want to do is whip up something complicated for dinner, but you also don't want to get tired of the same quick recipes you're cooking every single night. Our lemon chicken recipe is simple to cook with ingredients you may already have at home, and it's anything but boring. As an added bonus, it's low in calories, so you can feel great while still enjoying what you eat.

One of the biggest concerns when cooking chicken breast is that it might turn out dry. The fact that we bake the chicken in lemon butter for this recipe certainly helps, but the real secret is using MEATER to make sure your chicken is cooked to the perfect temperature!

While you can have a crisp salad as a side if you want to be super healthy, we encourage serving your chicken with a starch, like potatoes or rice, to fill out the meal. As an added bonus, these kinds of sides will soak up your extra sauce so you won't waste a drop of that lemony, buttery goodness.

If you've never cooked salmon before, it might seem like a daunting task. Salmon is well known for being healthy, and is typically found on the menu at pretty classy establishments, so no way it's also easy to cook. Well, as it turns out, yes way. You don't need any special equipment, just an oven and your favorite catch. You don't even need a lot of seasoning to make a scrumptious salmon meal, but throwing on a few fresh herbs will take your fish from great to extra great.

On top of being simple and healthy, salmon also doesn't take much time to cook. Because of this, there's a risk of overcooking, but luckily you've got MEATER by your side to keep that from happening!

In keeping with the easy and healthy theme, we like to serve our oven baked salmon with steamed vegetables or white rice.

items.name: Salmon Fillet
items.information:
About 1Â½ lb recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: Oil
items.information: Just enough to lightly coat the tray and the fish

meta.text: Thinly slice half of your lemon and set the other half aside.
Cut off your dill stems and finely chop the herbs until you have 1 tbsp.
Pull your thyme leaves off of the stems, and finely chop them until you have 1 tbsp.
Line your tray with parchment, then drizzle the parchment with oil.

We're big adopters of the "work smarter, not harder" philosophy. Lining the tray with parchment will make your kitchen clean-up easier, and oiling the parchment helps keep the salmon skin from sticking.
Pre-heat your oven to <temperature c="150" f="300" />. This can take up to 15m.
Feel the salmon flesh and pull out any bones.
Even if you bought your fish deboned, there's still a chance of sneaky bones left behind.
Put your salmon skin side down on the tray.
Sprinkle salt and pepper on the flesh side and pat it in.
Peel and mince your garlic (3 cloves).
If you'd like, add 1 tsp of cayenne pepper.
Coat the salmon flesh with your oil.
Sprinkle your chopped herbs on the salmon.
Lay the lemon slices on the salmon, and squeeze the rest of the lemon over the top.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the fillet.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the black ceramic handle, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Set your MEATER charger close to the smoker.

If you're using MEATER Plus or MEATER Block, the charging dock needs to stay as close to your cooker as possible so it can stay connected to the probe. From there, it'll boost the signal over Bluetooth or WiFi, depending on your model. If you're using the original MEATER, the charger won't have any repeater function, so you'll just want to keep your smart device close to the probe.
Pop the salmon in the oven.
Let your salmon rest on a cutting board.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Slice your salmon fillet into smaller steaks to serve.

description.text:
As much as we love cooking for special occasions, we can't forget about the everyday cooks. At the end of a long day, the last thing you want to do is whip up something complicated for dinner, but you also don't want to get tired of the same quick recipes you're cooking every single night. Our lemon chicken recipe is simple to cook with ingredients you may already have at home, and it's anything but boring. As an added bonus, it's low in calories, so you can feel great while still enjoying what you eat.

One of the biggest concerns when cooking chicken breast is that it might turn out dry. The fact that we bake the chicken in lemon butter for this recipe certainly helps, but the real secret is using MEATER to make sure your chicken is cooked to the perfect temperature!

While you can have a crisp salad as a side if you want to be super healthy, we encourage serving your chicken with a starch, like potatoes or rice, to fill out the meal. As an added bonus, these kinds of sides will soak up your extra sauce so you won't waste a drop of that lemony, buttery goodness.

items.name: 2 Chicken Breasts
items.information:
About 7 oz each recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: Oil
items.information:
Just enough to lightly coat the pan

Oils with higher smoke point recommended, like avocado or grapeseed oil

meta.text: Combine your dry herbs.

While a lot of lemon chicken recipes keep the herbs pretty simple, we wanted something a little more surprising and unique. Marjoram, rosemary, and oregano are classically used together in Italian recipes, and they work together to bring a strong and herby contrast to the tanginess of the lemon butter. If you can't find all of these herbs individually, you can use a ready-made mix of Italian herbs in a pinch.
Thinly slice half of your lemon and set the other half aside.
Pat your chicken breasts dry with paper towels.

You should always pat your meat dry so your seasonings will stick better. If you bought your chicken breasts pre-packaged at a grocery store, this also gets rid of any leftover liquid from the packaging.
Sprinkle salt and pepper all over, and pat it in.
Pre-heat your oven to 350Â°F. This can take up to 15m.

Chicken breast is a super lean meat, so it doesn't need to be cooked slowly since there's no fat to render. Instead, it's better to cook at a medium high temperature so it's ready faster, and so it ends up a lovely golden color instead of a weird pasty white.
Pre-heat your pan on high for 1m.
Lightly coat the pan with your oil.
Sear your chicken all over, just until it's golden brown.

The point of this step is just to create texture and color right on the surface of the chicken, not to actually cook it. Make sure not to leave it in the pan any longer than it takes to get the right texture, or the meat might start to dry out.
Move the chicken to your baking dish, but keep the pan hot.
Add your butter (4 tbsp) and the juice from the rest of the lemon to the hot pan.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the chicken breast.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the black ceramic handle, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Set your MEATER charger close to the oven.

If you're using MEATER Plus or MEATER Block, the charging dock needs to stay as close to your cooker as possible so it can stay connected to the probe. From there, it'll boost the signal over Bluetooth or WiFi, depending on your model. If you're using the original MEATER, the charger won't have any repeater function, so you'll just want to keep your smart device close to the probe.
Sprinkle the chicken with your herbs, and scatter the lemon slices in the dish.
Pour your lemon butter over the chicken.
Pop the chicken in the oven.
Let your chicken rest on a cutting board.

Carryover cooking lasts a lot longer on a hot surface, so smaller cuts like these ones need to be moved to a room temperature surface after you take them off of heat. If not, even lemon butter might not be able to save you from dry chicken.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Slice your chicken breasts and drizzle them with lemon butter to serve.

description.text:
So let's say you're a smoking pro, and you're looking for a recipe to shake things up between briskets. Or maybe you're hosting a party for people who both love barbecue and own yachts, and you need to cook something impressive. In either case, smoked duck breast should meet your needs pretty nicely.

Of course you never want to mess up when cooking your food, but it's especially important to get it right when you're cooking something fancy like duck. When it's overcooked, duck meat can end up really tough. But properly-cooked duck will be tender on the inside with gorgeous, deep red skin and crispy fat, and MEATER will help you calculate the perfect cook time to make that happen!

If you're going to indulge with your main course, why not do the same with your sides? Duck breast should be paired with a decadent French side dish, particularly something cheesy like potatoes au gratin.

items.name: Duck Breast
items.information:
About 10 oz recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

meta.text: Patience is a virtue, especially when you're cooking duck. Incorrectly cooked duck breast can end up tougher than your grandma's leather sandals, so it's best to take your time and enjoy the experience.

meta.pro_tip: The rich taste of duck meat goes well with warm, sweet flavors, so we recommend using maple pellets when smoking duck.

meta.text: The little fillets hang off of the breast and cook at a different faster than the rest of the meat, so it's better to just cut them off. If you don't want to waste good duck meat (and we can't blame you if you don't), you can cook the fillets separately and save them as a fancy duck snack for later.

meta.pro_tip: Trim fat remove fillets
Leave the meat in the freezer (fat side up) for 15m, score when partially frozen: will be very easy and precize cutting them as the fat is now solified.

meta.text: Scoring, or making cuts, helps the duck fat to cook through and render properly. As an added bonus, to the untrained eye, it just makes you look like one of those artsy chefs on TV.

Proper probe placement is the key to accurate readings from both of the sensors and calculating the right cook time. While our probes go through intense testing to make sure they're calibrated correctly, some factors can still influence the reading. The internal sensor (which is about 1" above the pointed end) should be right in the center of the thickest part of the meat, not too close to the surface, and avoiding bones or fatty sections. Insert the probe past the safety notch â…” of the way up, but be careful not to insert it all the way to the black ceramic portion, because this can influence the reading as well.
Allowing a longer rest gives the juices more time to redistribute, so we suggest resting for around 20m for the most tender and delicious result.
Leftover moisture on your duck will cause it to steam instead of sear, and you won't be able to achieve that beautiful crispy fat you're going for.

Cast iron is well known as the best material for heat conduction and retention, so it's ideal for pan searing. In this case, it's best to keep the heat at a medium level, since duck fat has a low smoke point and can burn easily.
Since texture is a big part of what makes this recipe special, we recommend spending extra time searing the fat so it turns out extra golden and crispy.
The melted butter and fat helps to continue crisping up the fat after flipping the breast, and adds to the beautiful golden brown color.

overlay_text.text: Sprinkle vigorously to crisp the fat

meta.text: You've just smoked a rich and juicy duck breast, and you've earned a reward. Acidic beverages like pinot noir work best for cutting through the fattiness of the duck meat.

description.text:
This is a beef dish that's loved universally, and can be enjoyed for pretty much any meal. Hearty dinners! Sunday roasts! Sandwich lunches! Breakfast, probably! Leaner roasts are more prone to drying out, but there are some ways to prevent that. First, if you can, try to find a roast with a good bit of marbling while you're shopping. Second, take your time and cook that baby low and slow.

Of course, hitting the perfect internal temperature is also key in achieving perfectly tender roast beef, so MEATER is your best friend for telling you when to remove that roast from the oven.

There are so many ways to enjoy a beef roast. For a casual meal, we love our big beef and cheddar sandwiches. If we're feeling ambitious, we'll go all out with potatoes, vegetables, and Yorkshire puddings for a proper Sunday carvery. With roast beef, you really can't go wrong with any red wine, but we recommend something a little more dry like cabernet sauvignon.

items.name: Rump Roast
items.information:
Rib-eye or sirloin roast can be used

4-5 lbs recommended

Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: 3 Tablespoons Oil
items.information: Oils with higher smoke point recommended, like avocado or grapeseed oil

meta.text: Pat your entire roast dry with paper towels.
Leftover moisture on your roast will make it steam instead of sear. This is great for a spa day, but not so much for getting a beautiful crust.
Wrap your twine around the roast, making a loop every 2".
Trussing your beef roast keeps it in a tidy cylindrical shape. This way, it'll cook more evenly than if it's just weirdly shaped and spilling out all over the place.
Sprinkle salt and pepper all over, and pat it in.
Pre-heat your oven to <temperature c="120" f="250" />. This can take up to 15m.

Since rump roast is a leaner cut of meat, it can end up hard to chew through if you cook it too quickly. Setting your oven to a lower temperature will keep the meat from drying out and the gristle from getting too tough.
Pre-heat your pan on high for 1m.
Add your oil, garlic, and herbs to the pan, and let the aroma release for 1m.

When you're searing with aromatics like garlic and herbs, these should be added to the pan just a little bit before the meat. This releases the flavor into the cooking oil, and the roast will absorb it more easily.
Add your butter, then sear your roast all over, just until it's golden brown.

The point of this step is just to create a crust right on the surface of the roast, not to cook the roast more. Make sure not to leave it in the pan any longer than it takes to get the right texture, or the meat might overcook. For leaner roasts, searing with butter adds moisture and flavor.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the roast.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the black ceramic handle, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Set your MEATER charger close to the oven.

If you're using MEATER Plus or MEATER Block, the charging dock needs to stay as close to your cooker as possible so it can stay connected to the probe. From there, it'll boost the signal over Bluetooth or WiFi, depending on your model. If you're using the original MEATER, the charger won't have any repeater function, so you'll just want to keep your smart device close to the probe.
Place the roast on your baking dish.

The key to this recipe is not letting the meat dry out, so we don't want to let the precious juices just drip out. Roasting with the meat directly in a baking dish means the roast will cook in the juice, keeping it nice and tender.
Stick the roast in the oven.
Let your roast rest on a cutting board.

Carryover cooking lasts a lot longer on a hot surface, so meat needs to be moved to a room temperature surface after you take it off of heat. If not, your medium rare roast may be closer to medium, or your well done roast may be closer to a chewy beef cylinder.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Snip off the twine with kitchen scissors.
Don't eat the twine. It's probably gross.
Cut your roast into thin slices to serve.

meta.text: Pre-heat your oven to <temperature c="120" f="250" />. This can take up to 15m.

They say good things come to those who wait, and this roast is no exception. As tempting as it might be to just hold onto the bones and set the whole thing ablaze like a proper caveperson, it's best to cook it slowly at a low temperature so the fat can properly render. This bastes the roast from the inside, which will mean a much more tender and flavorful result.
Mold the roast into a cylinder with your hands, then wrap your twine around it, making a loop every 2".
Trussing your beef roast keeps it in a tidy cylindrical shape. This way, it'll cook more evenly than if it's just weirdly shaped and spilling out all over the place.
Pick your rosemary leaves from the stems and finely chop them.
Pull the hard stems from your sage, and finely chop the leaves.
Sprinkle salt and pepper all over and pat it in.
Rub your rosemary and thyme into the roast.
Connect your MEATER device in the MEATER app.

If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the ambient sensor joint, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Set the roast on a rack and stick it in the oven.

Raised racks let heat flow all around the meat, which means better color and more even cooking. A foil-lined tray under the rack will seriously improve your life when it's time to clean up the kitchen. High five, past self.

Melt your butter (Â½ cup) on medium low, then set it aside.
Brush the roast with your butter every 30m.

Turn up your oven to <temperature c="230" f="450" />.
Give your roast one last coating of butter.

Put your roast back in the oven, fat side up, for 10m.

This bird is on FIRE. First, we made our own unique spin on Portuguese peri peri chicken, and shared our insanely tasty oven roasted recipe with the world. Now, we've one-upped ourselves by taking our spicy, tangy, lightly sweet chicken and chucking it on the grill for even more of a flavor explosion.

There are a few main tricks to getting a perfectly juicy bird with crispy skin. The first is spatchcocking the chicken so it cooks more evenly (which we'll cover in the recipe, so don't worry if you have no clue what that means). The second is starting with higher heat and reducing it partway through. And the third, of course, is your good friend MEATER letting you know when that fiery motherclucker is at the perfect internal temperature.

Because this chicken is made with spicy habanero peppers, it works best with milder side dishes like white rice or a fresh green salad. Or if you like the feeling of your mouth being on fire, you can just get some fresh vegetables and drown them in your extra peri peri sauce, you daredevil, you. Bitter beverages are known for making spicy sensations worse, so you can grab one of those if you're into that sort of thing, or you can find more relief with something with more sugar content. Fruity red wines like pinot noir or dark and sweet ales are your best bet.

items.information: Should be thawed to fridge temperature before starting cook

items.name: 2 Habanero Peppers
items.information:
If unavailable, substitute serrano or jalapeÃ±o peppers

Habanada peppers can be used for less heat

Pure sugar cane molasses recommended

If unavailable, substitute pomegranate molasses

meta.text: Cut off the lower parts of your cilantro stems.

Cilantro is a great complement to poultry dishes because it has a bit of a citrus flavor. It also has a strong herby flavor, so it's a perfect addition to a bold sauce like peri peri. Unless, of course, you have that weird olfactory gene variation that makes cilantro taste like soap.

meta.pro_tip: If you're curious about the habanero flavor but can't take the heat, there is a miracle of science called a habanada pepper, though this might be tricky to find in the wild.

meta.text: Cut the stems from your habanero peppers (2), then wash your hands.

We wanted this recipe to have a lot of heat while still maintaining flavor, so we chose habanero peppers for their unique sweet and spicy taste. After cooking, the chicken itself might be mild enough that it can be enjoyed by even the wimpiest of spice wimps, but our recipe calls for some uncooked sauce to be set aside (spoiler alert) for those who like to live dangerously. If you want your sauce to be less spicy, you can use fewer peppers, as well as remove the seeds and pith.
Pick off the stems from your basil leaves (15).

Basil is an aromatic herb with a touch of sweetness, so it helps to balance out the spiciness of the peppers and the acidity of the lemon juice. It's important to remove the stems, because no one likes a chewy sauce.
Peel your garlic (4 cloves).

Garlic is almost as much of a staple in savory dishes as salt and pepper. It's a powerhouse of flavor that pairs with and enhances foods of every flavor profile. Do you really need to add garlic to all of your recipes? That's like asking if you really need oxygen.

meta.pro_tip: If you can only find fresh bell peppers, roast them for 25m at 400Â°F, then remove the stems, skin, and seeds.

meta.text: Pat your peppers dry with paper towels.

Bell peppers are a big source of freshness and color in this sauce, but since raw bell peppers have a high water content, they have to be roasted. If the sauce is blended with fresh bell pepper, it will be way too watery, and you'll just end up marinating the baking tray instead of the chicken.

meta.html:
Put the following ingredients in the blender:
  • Habanero Peppers
  • Cilantro
  • Basil
  • Garlic
  • Roasted red peppers

meta.text: It's always best to put solid ingredients in the blender first, especially leafy ones. Otherwise, it's easier for chunky bits to get stuck at the top of the blender where they won't mix in properly.
Add in the rest of the sauce ingredients.
This combination of ingredients makes a beautifully thick and colorful sauce, and gives it a lot of complexity in its flavor. Your chicken will be spicy, smoky, tangy, and just a little bit sweet.
Blend the ingredients on high speed until your sauce is thick.
Scoop out Â¼ cup of your sauce and put it in the fridge for later.

meta.pro_tip: Cut the spine and wing tips from your chicken.
To make your life just a little bit easier, you might be able to ask someone at the butcher or meat counter to spatchcock the chicken for you when you buy it.

meta.text: With the breast side up, press down on the chicken until you hear a crack.

We won't fault you if you need a second of mental preparation before you do this step. Spatchcocking (flattening) a chicken isn't for the faint-hearted, but trust us when we say it's worth it. You'll get maximum heat exposure over the whole bird so the light and dark meat will cook more evenly, and it can even help your skin get crispier.
Pat your entire chicken dry with paper towels.
You should always pat your meat dry so your sauce will stick better. If you bought your chicken pre-packaged at a grocery store, this also gets rid of any leftover liquid from the packaging.

meta.pro_tip: While the sauce is the key to a good crust in this recipe, you can make the meat juicier by wet brining your chicken the day before cooking. Put the chicken in a large pot or brining bucket and submerge it completely in water, then add about 1Â¼ cup of salt per gallon of water. Place the container in your refrigerator and leave it for at least 12h.

meta.text: Spread a thick layer of peri peri sauce over the chicken.
The secret to a perfect crust is a nice, thick layer of sauce, so don't be stingy.
Turn two burners on medium high, close the lid, and let your grill hit <temperature c="200-250" f="400-475" />. This can take up to 15m.

Starting with higher heat lets your sauce and chicken cook together, and turning it down later in the cook will prevent the sauce ingredients from getting too charred. You want your face to burn, not your food.
Stick the chicken breast side up in the grill directly above the active burners, and cook it for 10m.
Turn the chicken over with your spatula.
Take the chicken out of the grill.
Turn off one burner, close the lid, and adjust the active burner to drop to <temperature c="160-170" f="325-350" />.
Put your probe in the center of the thickest part of the breast.

You've probably noticed that we really like talking about probe placement, but that's just because it's the single greatest key to an accurate cook. If the probe isn't in the thickest part of the meat, or isn't inserted to halfway between the minimum depth notch and the ambient sensor joint, the cook time estimate may be off and your food might not turn out the way you like it.
Put the chicken back in the grill next to the active burner, not directly above it. Wash your spatula and cooking surfaces.
Up to this point, we've still been dealing with raw chicken even after searing, so it's a good idea to wash anything that has come into contact with the chicken.
Set your MEATER charger close to the oven.

If you're using MEATER Plus or MEATER Block, the charging dock needs to stay as close to your cooker as possible so it can stay connected to the probe. From there, it'll boost the signal over Bluetooth or WiFi, depending on your model. If you're using the original MEATER, the charger won't have any repeater function, so you'll just want to keep your smart device close to the probe.
Let your chicken rest on a cutting board.

Carryover cooking lasts a lot longer on a hot surface, so meat needs to be moved to a room temperature surface after you take it off of heat. If not, you might end up looking at some pretty parched poultry.
Pull out the probe using oven mitts.
Serve the chicken with your extra sauce on the side.
We suggest side dishes like white rice or a crisp salad to cool you down from the spicy chicken. Sweeter beverages like fruity red wines or dark ales can also help out here.

You're probably used to thinking of pork as more of a casual protein, reserved for breakfasts, barbecues, and busy nights where you don't have a lot of time to cook. But who knew eating pork could be more of a luxury experience? Well, we did. And now you do too! True to its name, the tenderloin is the most tender and juicy cut of pork, but it doesn't carry quite as high a price tag as its beefy counterpart.

The key to perfect pork tenderloin is taking your time. Since it doesn't have as much fat as other cuts of pork, it can dry out if it's overcooked. Low and slow cooking is the best way to avoid this, along with using MEATER to make sure you're hitting the perfect internal temperature. Once that's done, just give it a sear so you'll still end up with a gorgeous golden brown crust.

Since this is a bit more of a high-end cut of pork, we recommend stepping it up from the usual veggies. Maybe opt for sautÃ©ed mushrooms or risotto. Or mushroom risotto! Refreshing beverages are the best option so you don't overpower your pork, so reach for a crisp cider or pinot noir.
